raw.text: In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.
raw.note: The foundational verse, establishing the initial set of unique words.

raw.text: May mercy, peace, and love be multiplied to you.
raw.note: This verse was selected as it contains words not found in the preceding verse.

raw.text: For great is His loving devotion to us, and the faithfulness of the LORD endures forever. Hallelujah!
raw.note: Chosen for its unique vocabulary compared to the preceding verses.

raw.text: The blessing of the LORD brings wealth, and He adds no trouble to it.
raw.note: This verse introduces new concepts and words not previously used.

raw.text: May the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all.
raw.note: A verse with significant theological terms, checked for uniqueness against the accumulated word list.

raw.text: “Speak to the Israelites and say to them: ‘When any of you brings an offering to the LORD, you may bring as your offering an animal from the herd or from the flock.
raw.note: Introduces the concept of offerings from the herd and flock.

raw.text: He declared to you His covenant, the Ten Commandments, which He commanded you to follow and then wrote on two stone tablets.
raw.note: Focuses on the covenant and the Ten Commandments on stone tablets.

raw.text: So the people shouted, and the priests blew the trumpets. And when the people heard the sound of the trumpet, they raised a great shout, and the wall collapsed. The people charged straight into the city, and they captured it.
raw.note: Describes the fall of Jericho's walls with trumpets and shouting.

raw.text: Reaching into his bag, David took out a stone and slung it, striking the Philistine on the forehead. The stone sank into his forehead, and he fell facedown on the ground.
raw.note: The iconic slaying of the Philistine giant by David.

raw.text: As they were walking along and talking, suddenly a chariot of fire with horses of fire appeared and separated the two of them, and Elijah went up to heaven in a whirlwind.
raw.note: Elijah's ascension into heaven by a whirlwind and chariot of fire.

raw.text: In the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, to fulfill the word of the LORD spoken by Jeremiah, the LORD moved the heart of Cyrus king of Persia to issue a proclamation throughout his realm and also to put it in writing:
raw.note: King Cyrus's proclamation to rebuild the temple, fulfilling Jeremiah's prophecy.

raw.text: So we rebuilt the wall until all of it was joined together up to half its height, for the people had a mind to work.
raw.note: Describes the diligent rebuilding of Jerusalem's wall.

raw.text: And the king loved Esther more than all the other women, and she won his grace and favor more than all the other virgins. So he set the royal crown on her head and made her queen instead of Vashti.
raw.note: Esther is crowned queen by the Persian king.

raw.text: “Where were you when I laid the foundations of the earth? Tell Me, if you have understanding.
raw.note: God's challenging question to Job about the creation of the world.

raw.text: There is a time for everything, and a season for every activity under the heavens:
raw.note: A famous reflection on the appointed time for all of life's events.

raw.text: The flowers appear on the earth; the season of singing has come, and the cooing of doves is heard in our land.
raw.note: A poetic description of the arrival of spring.

raw.text: And they called out to one another: “Holy, holy, holy is the LORD of Hosts; His glory fills the whole earth.”
raw.note: The seraphim's cry in Isaiah's vision of God's throne room.

raw.text: Because of the loving devotion of the LORD we are not consumed, for His compassions never fail.
raw.note: A lament that turns to hope in God's unfailing compassion.

raw.text: This is what the Lord GOD says to these bones: ‘I will cause breath to enter you, and you will come to life.
raw.note: The prophecy of the valley of dry bones, promising restoration.

raw.text: This is the inscription that was written: MENE, MENE, TEKEL, PARSIN.
raw.note: The mysterious writing on the wall during Belshazzar's feast.

raw.text: I led them with cords of human kindness, with ties of love. To them I was like one who lifts a little child to the cheek, and I bent down to feed them.
raw.note: A metaphor for God's gentle and loving guidance.

raw.text: And afterward, I will pour out My Spirit on all people. Your sons and daughters will prophesy, your old men will dream dreams, your young men will see visions.
raw.note: The promise of the outpouring of the Holy Spirit.

raw.text: But let justice roll on like a river, and righteousness like a never-failing stream.
raw.note: A powerful call for social justice and righteousness.

raw.text: Though you soar like the eagle and make your nest among the stars, from there I will bring you down,” declares the LORD.
raw.note: A prophecy of judgment against the prideful nation of Edom.

raw.text: He said: “In my distress I called to the LORD, and He answered me. From the depths of Sheol I called for help, and You listened to my cry.
raw.note: Jonah's prayer from within the great fish.

raw.text: He has shown you, O man, what is good. And what does the LORD require of you but to act justly, to love mercy, and to walk humbly with your God?
raw.note: A summary of God's requirement for justice, mercy, and humility.

raw.text: The LORD is good, a stronghold in the day of trouble. He knows those who take refuge in Him.
raw.note: A declaration of God's goodness and protection for those who trust Him.

raw.text: “Behold, the proud one’s soul is not right within him, but the righteous one will live by his faith.
raw.note: A foundational statement that the just live by faith.

raw.text: The LORD your God is in your midst—a mighty Savior! He will rejoice over you with gladness; He will quiet you with His love; He will rejoice over you with singing.”
raw.note: A joyful depiction of God delighting in His people.

raw.text: ‘The glory of this present house will be greater than the glory of the former house,’ says the LORD of Hosts. ‘And in this place I will grant peace,’ declares the LORD of Hosts.”
raw.note: A prophecy about the greater glory of the second temple.

raw.text: So he answered me, “This is the word of the LORD to Zerubbabel: ‘Not by might nor by power, but by My Spirit,’ says the LORD of Hosts.
raw.note: A reminder that God's work is accomplished by His Spirit, not human strength.

raw.text: “Behold, I will send My messenger, who will prepare the way before Me. Then the Lord whom you seek will suddenly come to His temple—the Messenger of the covenant, whom you desire, will surely come,” says the LORD of Hosts.
raw.note: A prophecy of a messenger who will prepare the way for the Lord.

raw.text: You are the light of the world. A city on a hill cannot be hidden.
raw.note: Jesus's description of his followers as the light of the world.

raw.text: He also said, “This is what the kingdom of God is like: A man scatters seed on the ground.
raw.note: The parable of the growing seed, illustrating the nature of God's kingdom.

raw.text: I tell you that in the same way, there will be more joy in heaven over one sinner who repents than over ninety-nine righteous persons who need no repentance.
raw.note: The joy in heaven over one repentant sinner.

raw.text: For God so loved the world that He gave His one and only Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish but have eternal life.
raw.note: Perhaps the most famous summary of the gospel message.

raw.text: But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit comes on you; and you will be My witnesses in Jerusalem, and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the ends of the earth.”
raw.note: The Great Commission given to the apostles to be witnesses to the world.

raw.text: For I am convinced that neither death nor life, neither angels nor principalities, neither the present nor the future, nor any powers,
raw.note: The beginning of a powerful declaration of the security of God's love.

raw.text: And now these three remain: faith, hope, and love; but the greatest of these is love.
raw.note: The three theological virtues: faith, hope, and love.

raw.text: Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation. The old has passed away; behold, the new has come.
raw.note: The transformative effect of being in Christ, becoming a new creation.

raw.text: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,
raw.note: The beginning of the list of the fruit of the Holy Spirit.

raw.text: For it is by grace you have been saved through faith, and this not from yourselves; it is the gift of God,
raw.note: A clear statement of salvation by grace through faith.

raw.text: I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me.
raw.note: A declaration of strength and enablement through Christ.

raw.text: For in Him all things were created, things in heaven and on earth, visible and invisible, whether thrones or dominions or rulers or authorities. All things were created through Him and for Him.
raw.note: A statement on the supremacy of Christ in creation.

raw.text: After that, we who are still alive and are left will be caught up together with them in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air. And so we will be with the Lord forever.
raw.note: A description of the rapture of the church.

raw.text: But the Lord is faithful, and He will strengthen you and protect you from the evil one.
raw.note: An assurance of God's faithfulness and protection.

raw.text: For the love of money is a root of all kinds of evil. By craving it, some have wandered away from the faith and pierced themselves with many sorrows.
raw.note: A warning against the love of money.

raw.text: All Scripture is God-breathed and is useful for teaching, rebuking, correcting, and training in righteousness,
raw.note: A key verse on the divine inspiration and usefulness of Scripture.

raw.text: He saved us, not by works of righteousness that we had done, but according to His mercy, through the washing of regeneration and renewal by the Holy Spirit,
raw.note: Salvation is based on mercy, not works, involving regeneration by the Spirit.

raw.text: I pray that your partnership in the faith may become effective in recognizing every good thing that is in us for the sake of Christ.
raw.note: A prayer for Philemon's faith to be effective.

raw.text: Now faith is the assurance of things hoped for, the conviction of things not seen.
raw.note: The classic definition of faith.

raw.text: As the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without deeds is dead.
raw.note: A strong statement on the relationship between faith and works.

raw.text: But you are a chosen people, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a people for God’s own possession, to proclaim the virtues of Him who called you out of darkness into His marvelous light.
raw.note: The identity of believers as a chosen people and royal priesthood.

raw.text: For no prophecy was ever produced by the will of man, but men spoke from God as they were carried along by the Holy Spirit.
raw.note: Explains the divine origin of prophecy.

raw.text: Whoever does not love does not know God, because God is love.
raw.note: A profound statement about the nature of God as love.

raw.text: And this is love: that we walk in obedience to His commands. This is the command, just as you have heard from the beginning: that you walk in love.
raw.note: Defines love as walking in obedience to God's commandments.

raw.text: I have no greater joy than to hear that my children are walking in the truth.
raw.note: An expression of joy over fellow believers walking in the truth.

raw.text: “I am the Alpha and the Omega,” says the Lord God, “who is, and who was, and who is to come, the Almighty.”
raw.note: A declaration of God's eternal and all-powerful nature.

raw.text: Then the LORD God formed man from the dust of the ground and breathed the breath of life into his nostrils, and the man became a living being.
raw.note: The creation of the first man from dust.

raw.text: God said to Moses, “I AM WHO I AM. This is what you are to say to the Israelites: ‘I AM has sent me to you.’”
raw.note: God reveals His covenant name, 'I AM', to Moses at the burning bush.

raw.text: The LORD bless you and keep you;
raw.note: The beginning of the Aaronic blessing.

raw.text: But Ruth replied: “Do not urge me to leave you or to turn back from you. Where you go I will go, and where you stay I will stay. Your people will be my people and your God my God.
raw.note: Ruth's profound declaration of loyalty to Naomi.

raw.text: Yours, O LORD, is the greatness and the power and the glory and the splendor and the majesty, for everything in heaven and on earth is Yours. Yours, O LORD, is the kingdom; You are exalted as Head over all.
raw.note: David's prayer of praise, ascribing all greatness and sovereignty to God.

raw.text: if My people who are called by My name will humble themselves and pray and seek My face and turn from their wicked ways, then I will hear from heaven, and I will forgive their sin and will heal their land.
raw.note: God's promise of forgiveness and healing in response to repentance.

raw.text: The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want.
raw.note: The opening of the Shepherd's Psalm, expressing trust and provision.

raw.text: Trust in the LORD with all your heart, and lean not on your own understanding.
raw.note: A call to wholehearted trust in God over self-reliance.

raw.text: But those who hope in the LORD will renew their strength. They will soar on wings like eagles; they will run and not grow weary, they will walk and not be faint.
raw.note: A promise of renewed strength for those who wait on the Lord.

raw.text: For I know the plans I have for you, declares the LORD, plans to prosper you and not to harm you, plans to give you hope and a future.
raw.note: A declaration of God's good and hopeful plans for His people in exile.

raw.text: But seek first the kingdom of God and His righteousness, and all these things will be added to you.
raw.note: The principle of prioritizing God's kingdom and righteousness.

raw.text: “Come to Me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest.
raw.note: Jesus's invitation to the weary to find rest in him.

raw.text: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
raw.note: The prologue of John, identifying Jesus as the eternal Word.

raw.text: Jesus answered, “I am the way and the truth and the life. No one comes to the Father except through Me.
raw.note: Jesus's exclusive claim to be the only way to God the Father.

raw.text: Do not be conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind. Then you will be able to test and approve what is the good, pleasing, and perfect will of God.
raw.note: A call to transformation through a renewed mind, rather than conformity to the world.

raw.text: For our struggle is not against flesh and blood, but against the rulers, against the authorities, against the powers of this dark world, and against the spiritual forces of evil in the heavenly realms.
raw.note: Describes the nature of spiritual warfare.

raw.text: For the word of God is living and active. Sharper than any double-edged sword, it pierces even to dividing soul and spirit, joints and marrow. It judges the thoughts and intentions of the heart.
raw.note: A description of the living and active nature of God's Word.

raw.text: ‘He will wipe away every tear from their eyes.’ There will be no more death or mourning or crying or pain, for the old order of things has passed away.”
raw.note: A vision of the new creation where sorrow and death are no more.

raw.text: You intended to harm me, but God intended it for good to accomplish what is now being done, the saving of many lives.
raw.note: Joseph's reflection on God's sovereignty in turning evil into good.

raw.text: You shall have no other gods before Me.
raw.note: The first of the Ten Commandments, demanding exclusive worship.

raw.text: Have I not commanded you? Be strong and courageous. Do not be afraid; do not be discouraged, for the LORD your God will be with you wherever you go.”
raw.note: God's charge to Joshua to be strong and courageous.

raw.text: When the three companies blew their trumpets and shattered their jars, they held the torches in their left hands and the trumpets in their right hands, and they shouted, “A sword for the LORD and for Gideon!”
raw.note: Gideon's unconventional battle strategy against the Midianites.

raw.text: But the LORD said to Samuel, “Do not look at his appearance or his height, for I have rejected him. For the LORD does not see as man sees; man looks at the outward appearance, but the LORD looks at the heart.”
raw.note: God's criteria for choosing a king is based on the heart, not appearance.

raw.text: Elijah went before all the people and said, “How long will you waver between two opinions? If the LORD is God, follow Him; but if Baal is God, follow him.” But the people did not answer him a word.
raw.note: Elijah's challenge to Israel on Mount Carmel to choose whom they will serve.

raw.text: “Be still, and know that I am God. I will be exalted among the nations, I will be exalted in the earth.”
raw.note: An invitation to cease striving and recognize God's sovereignty.

raw.text: Create in me a clean heart, O God, and renew a right spirit within me.
raw.note: David's prayer of repentance and for inner renewal.

raw.text: A man’s heart plans his way, but the LORD determines his steps.
raw.note: A proverb on the contrast between human plans and divine providence.

raw.text: For unto us a child is born, unto us a son is given, and the government will be upon His shoulders. And He will be called Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace.
raw.note: A famous prophecy of the Messiah and his kingly titles.

raw.text: But He was pierced for our transgressions, He was crushed for our iniquities; the punishment that brought us peace was upon Him, and by His stripes we are healed.
raw.note: A prophecy of the suffering servant, whose wounds bring healing.

raw.text: The heart is deceitful above all things and beyond cure—who can understand it?
raw.note: A stark assessment of the human heart's condition.

raw.text: Therefore go and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,
raw.note: The Great Commission, instructing disciples to make disciples of all nations.

raw.text: For even the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give His life as a ransom for many.”
raw.note: Jesus's statement about his purpose: to serve and give his life as a ransom.

raw.text: For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost.”
raw.note: Another summary of Jesus's mission to seek and save the lost.

raw.text: Then you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free.”
raw.note: A promise that knowing the truth leads to freedom.

raw.text: Jesus said to her, “I am the resurrection and the life. He who believes in Me will live, even though he dies.
raw.note: Jesus's declaration of his power over death.

raw.text: Salvation is found in no one else, for there is no other name under heaven given to men by which we must be saved.”
raw.note: Peter's declaration of the exclusivity of salvation through Jesus's name.

raw.text: for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God,
raw.note: A universal statement on the reality of sin.

raw.text: For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.
raw.note: Contrasts the consequence of sin (death) with the gift of God (eternal life).

raw.text: Therefore, my beloved brothers, be steadfast and immovable. Always excel in the work of the Lord, because you know that your labor in the Lord is not in vain.
raw.note: An encouragement to be steadfast in the Lord's work.

raw.text: I have been crucified with Christ, and I no longer live, but Christ lives in me. The life I live in the body, I live by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave Himself for me.
raw.note: A profound statement of identification with Christ in his death and resurrection.

raw.text: Let this mind be in you which was also in Christ Jesus:
raw.note: A call to have the same humble mindset as Christ.

raw.text: For God has not given us a spirit of fear, but of power, love, and self-control.
raw.note: Contrasts the spirit of fear with the Spirit of power, love, and self-discipline.

raw.text: Let us fix our eyes on Jesus, the author and perfecter of our faith, who for the joy set before Him endured the cross, scorning its shame, and sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.
raw.note: Describes Jesus as the pioneer and perfecter of faith, focusing on his endurance.

raw.text: Cast all your anxiety on Him, because He cares for you.
raw.note: An invitation to cast anxieties on God because of His care.

raw.text: Behold, I stand at the door and knock. If anyone hears My voice and opens the door, I will come in to him and dine with him, and he with Me.
raw.note: A famous depiction of Jesus seeking fellowship with individuals.

raw.text: And the reason the dream was given to Pharaoh in two forms is that the matter has been firmly decided by God, and God will do it soon.”
raw.note: Joseph's interpretation of Pharaoh's dream, explaining that its repetition signifies divine certainty and imminence.

raw.text: It will be a sign between Me and the Israelites forever, for in six days the LORD made the heavens and the earth, and on the seventh day He rested and was refreshed.’”
raw.note: The Sabbath described not just as rest, but as a perpetual sign of the covenant, reflecting God's own refreshment after creation.

raw.text: “You are to rise in the presence of the elderly, honor the aged, and fear your God. I am the LORD.
raw.note: A specific command from the Holiness Code to show respect and honor to the elderly.

raw.text: I see him, but not now; I behold him, but not near. A star will come out of Jacob; a scepter will rise out of Israel. He will crush the foreheads of Moab and tear down all the sons of Sheth.
raw.note: From Balaam's oracle, a famous messianic prophecy of a future ruler emerging from Israel.

raw.text: He humbled you, causing you to hunger and then feeding you with manna, which neither you nor your fathers had known, to teach you that man does not live on bread alone, but on every word that comes from the mouth of the LORD.
raw.note: Moses's explanation for the purpose of the manna: to teach reliance on God's word, not just physical food.

raw.text: The commander of the LORD’s army replied, “Take off your sandals, for the place where you are standing is holy.” And Joshua did so.
raw.note: The encounter between Joshua and the angelic commander, signifying the ground is holy due to divine presence.

raw.text: So he said to them: “Out of the eater came something to eat, and out of the strong came something sweet.” For three days they could not solve the riddle.
raw.note: Samson's riddle to the Philistines, based on his encounter with the lion and the honeycomb.

raw.text: “The LORD bless him!” Naomi said to her daughter-in-law. “He has not stopped showing his kindness to the living and the dead.” She added, “That man is our close relative; he is one of our kinsman-redeemers.”
raw.note: Naomi's joyful recognition of Boaz as a kinsman-redeemer, a key concept in the story of Ruth.

raw.text: And David was greatly distressed because the men were talking of stoning him; each man was bitter in spirit because of his sons and daughters. But David strengthened himself in the LORD his God.
raw.note: David's response in a moment of deep crisis and rejection, finding strength in God alone.

raw.text: For we will surely die and are like water spilled on the ground, which cannot be gathered up again. But God does not take away life; instead, He devises ways so that a banished person may not remain estranged from Him.
raw.note: The wise woman of Tekoa's argument to David, highlighting God's restorative and reconciling nature.

raw.text: and observe the requirements of the LORD your God, walking in His ways and keeping His statutes, commandments, ordinances, and testimonies, as written in the Law of Moses, so that you may prosper in all you do and wherever you turn,
raw.note: David's final charge to Solomon, emphasizing that prosperity is tied to obedience to God's law.

raw.text: Then they served it for the men to eat, but as they began to eat the stew, they cried out, “O man of God, there is death in the pot!” And they could not eat it.
raw.note: The cry of the prophets after eating a poisonous stew, setting the stage for Elisha's miracle of purification.

raw.text: from Issachar, men who understood the times and knew what Israel should do—200 chiefs with all their relatives under their command;
raw.note: A description of the men of Issachar, valued for their wisdom and discernment of the times.

raw.text: Early in the morning they set out for the Desert of Tekoa. As they set out, Jehoshaphat stood and said, “Listen to me, O Judah and people of Jerusalem! Have faith in the LORD your God and you will be upheld; have faith in His prophets and you will be successful.”
raw.note: King Jehoshaphat's exhortation to the people before battle, linking faith in God and His prophets to victory.

raw.text: For Ezra had devoted himself to the study and observance of the Law of the LORD, and to teaching its statutes and ordinances in Israel.
raw.note: The three-fold resolve of Ezra: to study, to practice, and to teach the Law of God.

raw.text: So they read from the Book of the Law of God, explaining it and giving the meaning so that the people could understand the reading.
raw.note: A model of biblical exposition, where the reading of Scripture was accompanied by clear explanation.

raw.text: “Go, gather all the Jews who are in Susa, and fast for me. Do not eat or drink for three days, night or day. I and my maids will fast as you do. When this is done, I will go to the king, even though it is against the law. And if I perish, I perish.”
raw.note: Esther's courageous and sacrificial decision to risk her life for her people.

raw.text: “I have made a covenant with my eyes. How then could I gaze at a virgin?
raw.note: Job's declaration of his commitment to personal purity, even in his thoughts and glances.

raw.text: He who has clean hands and a pure heart, who does not lift up his soul to an idol or swear by what is false.
raw.note: The qualifications for one who would ascend to God's holy place, emphasizing internal purity and external integrity.

raw.text: Unless the LORD builds the house, its builders labor in vain. Unless the LORD watches over the city, the watchmen stand guard in vain.
raw.note: A wisdom psalm on the futility of human effort apart from divine blessing and providence.

raw.text: A word aptly spoken is like apples of gold in settings of silver.
raw.note: A proverb describing the beauty and value of timely and appropriate words.

raw.text: Cast your bread upon the waters, for after many days you will find it again.
raw.note: A proverb encouraging generous and speculative action, with the expectation of a future return.

raw.text: I form the light and create darkness, I bring prosperity and create disaster; I, the LORD, do all these things.
raw.note: A strong declaration of God's absolute sovereignty over all aspects of existence, both good and calamitous.

raw.text: You will seek Me and find Me when you search for Me with all your heart.
raw.note: A promise that a wholehearted search for God will be successful.

raw.text: TEKEL: You have been weighed on the scales and found wanting.
raw.note: The interpretation of the second word written on the wall, signifying King Belshazzar's moral and spiritual deficiency.

raw.text: Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called sons of God.
raw.note: One of the Beatitudes, conferring a special blessing and identity on those who actively make peace.

raw.text: Jesus looked at them and said, “With man this is impossible, but not with God. For all things are possible with God.”
raw.note: Jesus's teaching on salvation, emphasizing that what is impossible for humans is possible for God.

raw.text: Whoever is faithful in very little is also faithful in much, and whoever is dishonest in very little is also dishonest in much.
raw.note: A principle of stewardship, teaching that faithfulness in small matters is indicative of character.

raw.text: By this all men will know that you are My disciples, if you love one another.”
raw.note: Jesus's declaration that mutual love is the defining mark of His followers.

raw.text: From one man He made every nation of men, that they should inhabit the whole earth; and He determined their appointed times and the boundaries of their lands.
raw.note: From Paul's sermon in Athens, a statement on God's sovereign role in creating and governing all nations.

raw.text: Do not be overcome by evil, but overcome evil with good.
raw.note: A command to proactively counter evil with good, rather than retaliating in kind.

raw.text: Do you not know that in a race all the runners run, but only one receives the prize? Run in such a way as to win the prize.
raw.note: An athletic metaphor for the Christian life, urging disciplined effort toward the goal.

raw.text: Brothers, if someone is caught in a trespass, you who are spiritual should restore him gently. But watch yourself, or you also may be tempted.
raw.note: An instruction on church discipline, emphasizing a spirit of gentleness in restoration.

raw.text: Let no unwholesome talk come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building others up according to their needs, that it may benefit those who listen.
raw.note: A command regarding speech, that it should be constructive and beneficial to others.

raw.text: I am not saying this out of need, for I have learned to be content in any circumstance.
raw.note: Paul's testimony of having learned the secret of contentment regardless of his external situation.

raw.text: Set your minds on things above, not on earthly things.
raw.note: A command for believers to orient their thinking and desires toward heavenly realities.

raw.text: pray without ceasing,
raw.note: A concise but profound command to maintain a constant attitude and practice of prayer.

raw.text: Therefore, if anyone cleanses himself from what is dishonorable, he will be an instrument for noble purposes, made holy, useful to the Master, and prepared for every good work.
raw.note: A metaphor describing a cleansed person as a useful instrument for God's noble purposes.

raw.text: Keep your lives free from the love of money and be content with what you have, because God has said, “Never will I leave you; never will I forsake you.”
raw.note: An exhortation to contentment, grounded in the certainty of God's unfailing presence.

raw.text: My dear brothers, take note of this: Everyone should be quick to listen, slow to speak, and slow to become angry,
raw.note: Practical wisdom for interpersonal communication, prioritizing listening over speaking and anger.

raw.text: Finally, all of you, be like-minded and sympathetic, love as brothers, be tenderhearted and humble.
raw.note: A summary of virtues required for harmonious community life.

raw.text: But grow in the grace and knowledge of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. To Him be the glory both now and forever. Amen.
raw.note: The final instruction of Peter's second epistle, a call to continuous spiritual growth.

raw.text: This is how we know what love is: Jesus Christ laid down His life for us. And we ought to lay down our lives for our brothers.
raw.note: Defining love by the ultimate sacrificial act of Christ, which becomes the model for believers.

raw.text: I am coming soon. Hold on to what you have, so that no one will take your crown.
raw.note: Christ's urgent message to the church in Philadelphia, encouraging perseverance in light of His imminent return.

raw.text: The scepter will not depart from Judah, nor the ruler’s staff from between his feet, until he to whom it belongs comes and the obedience of the nations is his.
raw.note: Jacob's prophecy over his son Judah, foretelling a perpetual royal lineage that culminates in a messianic figure.

raw.text: The LORD is my strength and my song, and He has become my salvation. He is my God, and I will praise Him, my father’s God, and I will exalt Him.
raw.note: From the Song of Moses after the Red Sea crossing, one of the earliest recorded hymns of praise in the Bible.

raw.text: I will walk among you and be your God, and you will be My people.
raw.note: A key promise of the Mosaic Covenant, expressing God's desire for intimate fellowship with His people.

raw.text: But if you fail to do this, you will be sinning against the LORD; and you may be sure that your sin will find you out.
raw.note: Moses's warning to the tribes of Reuben and Gad about the inescapable consequences of sin.

raw.text: And now, O Israel, what does the LORD your God ask of you but to fear the LORD your God, to walk in all His ways, to love Him, to serve the LORD your God with all your heart and with all your soul,
raw.note: A summary of the core requirements of the covenant relationship with God.

raw.text: So on that day Moses swore to me, ‘The land on which your feet have walked will be your inheritance and that of your children forever, because you have followed the LORD my God wholeheartedly.’
raw.note: Caleb recounting the promise made to him by Moses as a reward for his faithful report.

raw.text: In those days Israel had no king; everyone did what was right in his own eyes.
raw.note: The recurring and concluding refrain of the book of Judges, highlighting the chaos of anarchy.

raw.text: Then the women said to Naomi, “Blessed be the LORD, who has not left you without a kinsman-redeemer today. May his name be famous in Israel.
raw.note: The women's blessing to Naomi, celebrating the birth of Obed who would secure the family line.

raw.text: David said to the Philistine, “You come against me with sword and spear and javelin, but I come against you in the name of the LORD of Hosts, the God of the armies of Israel, whom you have defied.
raw.note: David's declaration of faith before fighting Goliath, contrasting human weapons with God's power.

raw.text: Now be pleased to bless the house of Your servant, that it may continue forever in Your presence. For You, O Lord GOD, have spoken, and with Your blessing the house of Your servant will be blessed forever.”
raw.note: The conclusion of David's prayer in response to the Davidic Covenant, asking for the fulfillment of God's promise.

raw.text: Answer me, O LORD, answer me, so that these people will know that You, O LORD, are God, and that You are turning their hearts back again.”
raw.note: Elijah's prayer on Mount Carmel, focused not on his own vindication but on revealing God's identity and restoring the people.

raw.text: So now, O LORD our God, please save us from his hand, so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that You alone, O LORD, are God.”
raw.note: Hezekiah's prayer for deliverance from the Assyrians, with the ultimate goal of glorifying God among the nations.

raw.text: “But who am I, and who are my people, that we should be able to give as generously as this? For everything comes from You, and we have given You only what comes from Your own hand.
raw.note: David's humble recognition that all wealth and the ability to give generously ultimately come from God.

raw.text: With him is only an arm of flesh, but with us is the LORD our God to help us and to fight our battles.” And the people were encouraged by the words of Hezekiah king of Judah.
raw.note: Hezekiah's encouragement to the people of Judah, contrasting the limited power of their enemies with the infinite power of God.

raw.text: So we fasted and petitioned our God about this, and He answered our prayer.
raw.note: Ezra's account of seeking God's protection for their journey through fasting and prayer.

raw.text: After I looked things over, I stood up and said to the nobles, the officials, and the rest of the people, “Don’t be afraid of them. Remember the Lord, who is great and awesome, and fight for your brothers, your sons and your daughters, your wives and your homes.”
raw.note: Nehemiah's exhortation to the builders of the wall, motivating them to fight by remembering God's greatness.

raw.text: For the Jews it was a time of light and joy and gladness and honor.
raw.note: The description of the celebration after the decree was reversed, a complete turnaround from their previous state of dread.

raw.text: But He knows the way that I take; when He has tested me, I will come forth as gold.
raw.note: Job's expression of faith that God's testing, though painful, would ultimately prove and refine his character.

raw.text: When I am afraid, I will trust in You.
raw.note: A simple yet profound declaration of the psalmist's choice to respond to fear with trust in God.

raw.text: He will cover you with His feathers, and under His wings you will find refuge; His faithfulness will be your shield and rampart.
raw.note: A series of metaphors describing the comprehensive and secure protection God provides to those who trust in Him.

raw.text: Do not boast about tomorrow, for you do not know what a day may bring.
raw.note: A wisdom saying cautioning against arrogance about the future due to its inherent uncertainty.

raw.text: Remember your Creator in the days of your youth, before the days of trouble come and the years approach when you will say, “I find no pleasure in them”
raw.note: An exhortation to seek God early in life, before the difficulties and weariness of old age set in.

raw.text: Yet You, O LORD, are our Father; we are the clay, and You are the potter; we are all the work of Your hand.
raw.note: A powerful metaphor for God's sovereignty and creative power over His people.

raw.text: They will fight against you but will not overcome you, for I am with you to rescue you,” declares the LORD.
raw.note: God's promise to Jeremiah, assuring him of divine protection and deliverance despite intense opposition.

raw.text: For this reason a man will leave his father and mother and be united to his wife, and they will become one flesh.
raw.note: A foundational statement on the nature of marriage, defining it as a one-flesh union.

raw.text: By day the LORD went ahead of them in a pillar of cloud to guide them on their way, and by night in a pillar of fire to give them light, so that they could travel by day or night.
raw.note: The description of God's miraculous guidance of Israel in the wilderness through pillars of cloud and fire.

raw.text: For the life of a creature is in the blood, and I have given it to you to make atonement for yourselves on the altar; it is the blood that makes atonement for one’s life.
raw.note: A key theological statement on the significance of blood in the sacrificial system for making atonement.

raw.text: the LORD make His face shine upon you and be gracious to you;
raw.note: The second part of the Aaronic blessing, a prayer for God's favor and grace.

raw.text: If a prophet speaks in the name of the LORD but the thing does not take place or prove true, it is a message the LORD has not spoken. The prophet has spoken presumptuously. Do not be afraid of him.
raw.note: The test for a true prophet: the fulfillment of their prophecies.

raw.text: No one will be able to stand against you all the days of your life. As I was with Moses, so I will be with you; I will never leave you nor forsake you.
raw.note: God's promise of His unfailing presence and support to Joshua as he leads Israel.

raw.text: When he saw her, he tore his clothes and cried, “Oh, my daughter! You have brought me to my knees! You have become the source of my trouble. For I have made a vow to the LORD and I cannot take it back.”
raw.note: Jephthah's tragic realization of the consequences of his rash vow.

raw.text: At this, they wept aloud again. Then Orpah kissed her mother-in-law goodbye, but Ruth clung to her.
raw.note: The pivotal moment of decision, where Ruth's loyalty is contrasted with Orpah's departure.

raw.text: After David had finished talking with Saul, Jonathan became one in spirit with David, and he loved him as himself.
raw.note: The beginning of the deep friendship and covenant love between David and Jonathan.

raw.text: The king was shaken. He went up to the room over the gateway and wept. And as he went, he said: “O my son Absalom! My son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you! O Absalom, my son, my son!”
raw.note: David's heart-wrenching lament over the death of his rebellious son, Absalom.

raw.text: But he himself went a day’s journey into the wilderness. He came to a broom tree, sat down under it, and prayed that he might die. “I have had enough, LORD,” he said. “Take my life, for I am no better than my fathers.”
raw.note: Elijah's moment of despair and exhaustion in the wilderness after his victory on Mount Carmel.

raw.text: “Go and inquire of the LORD for me, for the people and for all Judah about what is written in this book that has been found. For great is the wrath of the LORD that is kindled against us because our fathers have not obeyed the words of this book, nor have they done according to all that is written for us.”
raw.note: King Josiah's reaction upon hearing the words of the newly discovered Book of the Law.

raw.text: And now, You have been pleased to bless the house of Your servant, that it may continue forever before You. For You, O LORD, have blessed it, and it will be blessed forever.”
raw.note: The conclusion of David's prayer, expressing faith in the permanence of God's promised blessing.

raw.text: My sons, do not be negligent now, for the LORD has chosen you to stand before Him, to minister to Him, and to be His ministers and burn incense.”
raw.note: Hezekiah's charge to the Levites to purify themselves and the temple, urging them not to neglect their duties.

raw.text: So the family heads of Judah and Benjamin, along with the priests and Levites—everyone whose spirit God had moved—prepared to go up and build the house of the LORD in Jerusalem.
raw.note: The response to Cyrus's decree, highlighting God's role in stirring the spirits of the people to return.

raw.text: Remember me for this, O my God, and do not blot out my deeds of loving devotion for the house of my God and for its services.
raw.note: One of Nehemiah's characteristic prayers, asking God to remember his faithful work.

raw.text: That night, the king could not sleep; so he ordered the book of the chronicles, the record of his reign, to be brought in and read to him.
raw.note: The pivotal moment of divine providence where the king's insomnia leads to the honoring of Mordecai.

raw.text: Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind and said:
raw.note: The introduction to God's direct response to Job, speaking from a storm.

raw.text: Blessed is he whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered.
raw.note: A beatitude from a penitential psalm, describing the happiness of one who has received forgiveness.

raw.text: The stone the builders rejected has become the cornerstone.
raw.note: A messianic prophecy, quoted frequently in the New Testament, about the rejected but ultimately exalted stone.

raw.text: Commit your works to the LORD, and your plans will be established.
raw.note: A proverb advising reliance on God for the success of one's plans.

raw.text: There is nothing better for a man than to eat and drink and to find joy in his work. This too, I saw, is from the hand of God.
raw.note: The Preacher's conclusion that the ability to enjoy the simple pleasures of life is a gift from God.

raw.text: He will swallow up death forever. The Lord GOD will wipe away the tears from all faces; He will remove the disgrace of His people from all the earth. For the LORD has spoken.
raw.note: A prophecy of the final victory over death and the removal of all sorrow.

raw.text: “I, the LORD, search the heart; I test the mind to reward a man according to his ways, according to the fruit of his deeds.”
raw.note: A declaration of God's omniscience, that He examines the inner motives and judges accordingly.

raw.text: Let us examine and test our ways, and let us return to the LORD.
raw.note: A call to self-examination and repentance in the midst of suffering.

raw.text: And I will give them a single heart and I will put a new spirit within them; I will remove their heart of stone and give them a heart of flesh,
raw.note: A promise of the New Covenant, involving internal transformation and unity of heart.

raw.text: In my vision at night I looked, and there before me was one like a son of man, coming with the clouds of heaven. He approached the Ancient of Days and was led into His presence.
raw.note: Daniel's vision of the 'son of man' figure receiving authority and glory from God.

raw.text: Take My yoke upon you and learn from Me; for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls.
raw.note: Jesus's invitation to discipleship, described as taking on His gentle and restful yoke.

raw.text: Then He said, “He who has ears to hear, let him hear.”
raw.note: Jesus's recurring call for spiritual attentiveness and understanding.

raw.text: And Jesus grew in wisdom and stature, and in favor with God and man.
raw.note: A summary of Jesus's holistic development during his childhood.

raw.text: “I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep.
raw.note: One of Jesus's 'I Am' statements, identifying Himself as the self-sacrificing shepherd.

raw.text: In everything I have shown you that by hard work we must help the weak, remembering the words of the Lord Jesus Himself: ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’”
raw.note: Paul quoting a saying of Jesus that emphasizes the virtue of giving over receiving.

raw.text: Therefore, there is now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus.
raw.note: A foundational declaration of the believer's freedom from condemnation through union with Christ.

raw.text: For what I received I passed on to you as of first importance: that Christ died for our sins according to the Scriptures,
raw.note: The beginning of an early Christian creed, outlining the core tenets of the gospel.

raw.text: Examine yourselves to see whether you are in the faith; test yourselves. Can’t you see for yourselves that Jesus Christ is in you—unless, of course, you fail the test?
raw.note: A call to self-examination to confirm the genuineness of one's faith.

raw.text: So I say, walk by the Spirit, and you will not gratify the desires of the flesh.
raw.note: The key to overcoming sinful desires: living in dependence on the Holy Spirit.

raw.text: Do not get drunk on wine, which leads to debauchery. Instead, be filled with the Spirit.
raw.note: A contrast between being controlled by wine and being filled (controlled) by the Holy Spirit.

raw.text: I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus.
raw.note: Paul's athletic metaphor for his focused and determined pursuit of his heavenly calling.

raw.text: To them God has chosen to make known among the Gentiles the glorious riches of this mystery, which is Christ in you, the hope of glory.
raw.note: The revelation of the gospel mystery: the indwelling Christ as the source of the hope of future glory.

raw.text: and to make it your ambition to lead a quiet life: You should mind your own business and work with your hands, just as we told you,
raw.note: An instruction for believers to live quiet, responsible, and diligent lives.

raw.text: And as for you, brothers, never tire of doing what is right.
raw.note: An encouragement to persevere in doing good without becoming weary.

raw.text: If anyone does not provide for his own, and especially for his own household, he has denied the faith and is worse than an unbeliever.
raw.note: A strong statement on the responsibility of believers to provide for their own families.

raw.text: Endure hardship with us like a good soldier of Christ Jesus.
raw.note: A military metaphor encouraging Timothy to embrace hardship as part of his service to Christ.

raw.text: In everything, show yourself to be an example by doing good works. In your teaching, show integrity, dignity,
raw.note: Instructions for Titus on the importance of personal example and character in teaching.

raw.text: Make every effort to live in peace with all men and to be holy; without holiness no one will see the Lord.
raw.note: A command to pursue both peace with others and personal holiness, which is essential for seeing God.

raw.text: But the wisdom that comes from heaven is first of all pure; then peace-loving, considerate, submissive, full of mercy and good fruit, impartial and sincere.
raw.note: A description of the characteristics of divine wisdom, contrasting it with worldly wisdom.

raw.text: Therefore, prepare your minds for action; be self-controlled; set your hope fully on the grace to be given you when Jesus Christ is revealed.
raw.note: An exhortation to mental readiness and self-control, with hope fixed on future grace.

raw.text: Therefore, my brothers, be all the more eager to make your calling and election sure. For if you do these things, you will never fall,
raw.note: A call for diligence in Christian living as a means of confirming one's salvation.

raw.text: My little children, I am writing these things to you so that you will not sin. But if anyone does sin, we have an advocate with the Father—Jesus Christ, the Righteous One.
raw.note: An assurance of Christ's role as an advocate for believers when they sin.

raw.text: Blessed is the one who reads the words of this prophecy, and blessed are those who hear it and take to heart what is written in it, because the time is near.
raw.note: A unique blessing promised to those who read, hear, and obey the prophecy of Revelation.

raw.text: Then the man said, “Your name will no longer be Jacob, but Israel, because you have struggled with God and with men and have overcome.”
raw.note: The renaming of Jacob to Israel after his wrestling match, signifying his new identity.

raw.text: and you will be for Me a kingdom of priests and a holy nation.’ These are the words you are to speak to the Israelites.”
raw.note: God's stated purpose for Israel at Mount Sinai: to be a holy nation and a kingdom of priests.

raw.text: For the LORD your God is a consuming fire, a jealous God.
raw.note: A description of God's intense holiness and His demand for exclusive worship.

raw.text: “There is no one holy like the LORD; there is no one besides You; there is no Rock like our God.
raw.note: From Hannah's prayer, a declaration of God's unique holiness and stability.

raw.text: God is our refuge and strength, an ever-present help in trouble.
raw.note: A psalm celebrating God as a constant source of protection and help.

raw.text: but whoever listens to me will live in safety and be at ease, without fear of harm.”
raw.note: The promise of security and peace for those who follow the path of wisdom.

raw.text: so is My word that goes out from My mouth: It will not return to Me empty, but will accomplish what I desire and achieve the purpose for which I sent it.
raw.note: A powerful metaphor for the efficacy and purposefulness of God's word.

raw.text: But blessed is the man who trusts in the LORD, whose confidence is in Him.
raw.note: A beatitude for the one whose trust and confidence are placed in the LORD.

raw.text: For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.
raw.note: A principle teaching that one's heart and devotion follow what one values most.

raw.text: “I am the vine; you are the branches. If a man remains in Me and I in him, he will bear much fruit; apart from Me you can do nothing.
raw.note: Jesus's metaphor of the vine and branches to illustrate the believer's complete dependence on Him for spiritual fruitfulness.

raw.text: O, the depth of the riches of the wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable His judgments, and untraceable His ways!
raw.note: A doxology praising the profound and incomprehensible wisdom and knowledge of God.

raw.text: For no one can lay a foundation other than the one already laid, which is Jesus Christ.
raw.note: A statement on the exclusive and foundational role of Jesus Christ for the church.

raw.text: For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, that each one may receive what is due him for the things done while in the body, whether good or bad.
raw.note: A statement on the future judgment of believers, where their works will be evaluated.

raw.text: Consequently, you are no longer foreigners and strangers, but fellow citizens with God’s people and members of God’s household,
raw.note: A description of the new identity of Gentile believers, who are now fully included in God's family.

raw.text: And my God will supply all your needs according to His glorious riches in Christ Jesus.
raw.note: A promise of God's complete provision for believers, based on His infinite resources in Christ.

raw.text: who wants all men to be saved and to come to a knowledge of the truth.
raw.note: A statement on God's universal desire for the salvation of all people.

raw.text: For we do not have a high priest who is unable to sympathize with our weaknesses, but we have one who has been tempted in every way, just as we are—yet was without sin.
raw.note: An encouragement based on Christ's ability to sympathize with human weakness, as He was tempted yet remained sinless.

raw.text: Humble yourselves, therefore, under God’s mighty hand, that He may lift you up in due time.
raw.note: A command to humility with the promise of future exaltation by God.

raw.text: So when the Midianite merchants came by, his brothers pulled Joseph out of the cistern and sold him for twenty shekels of silver to the Ishmaelites, who took him to Egypt.
raw.note: The betrayal of Joseph by his brothers, selling him into slavery.

raw.text: Each one threw down his staff, and it became a snake. But Aaron’s staff swallowed up their staffs.
raw.note: The contest between Aaron's staff and those of the Egyptian magicians, demonstrating God's superior power.

raw.text: So fire came out from the presence of the LORD and consumed them, and they died before the LORD.
raw.note: The judgment on Nadab and Abihu for offering unauthorized fire in the Tabernacle.

raw.text: Then Moses raised his arm and struck the rock twice with his staff. Water gushed out, and the community and their livestock drank.
raw.note: Moses striking the rock at Meribah, an act of disobedience that brought forth water but had severe consequences.

raw.text: Moses was a hundred and twenty years old when he died, yet his eyes were not weak nor his strength gone.
raw.note: A description of Moses's remarkable vitality even at the time of his death.

raw.text: At that time Joshua imposed this oath: “Cursed before the LORD is the man who rises up and rebuilds this city, Jericho. At the cost of his firstborn he will lay its foundations; at the cost of his youngest he will set up its gates.”
raw.note: Joshua's curse upon anyone who would attempt to rebuild the city of Jericho.

raw.text: The Spirit of the LORD came upon him, and he became Israel’s judge. He went to war, and the LORD delivered Cushan-rishathaim king of Aram into his hands.
raw.note: The account of Othniel, the first judge, who was empowered by God's Spirit to deliver Israel.

raw.text: She named the boy Ichabod, saying, “The glory has departed from Israel,” because the ark of God had been captured and because of her father-in-law and her husband.
raw.note: The naming of Ichabod, meaning 'no glory,' signifying the tragedy of the Ark's capture by the Philistines.

raw.text: But David continued up the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went. His head was covered, and he was walking barefoot. And all the people with him covered their heads and went up, weeping as they went.
raw.note: David's sorrowful flight from Jerusalem during Absalom's rebellion, a picture of deep grief and humiliation.

raw.text: When all Israel saw that the king had refused to listen to them, they answered the king: “What share do we have in David, what part in Jesse’s son? To your tents, O Israel! Look after your own house, O David!”
raw.note: The rebellious cry of the northern tribes, marking the formal division of the kingdom.

raw.text: He removed the high places, shattered the sacred pillars, and cut down the Asherah poles. He also broke into pieces the bronze snake that Moses had made, for up to that time the Israelites had been burning incense to it.
raw.note: A summary of King Hezekiah's religious reforms, purging the land of idolatry.

raw.text: But King David replied to Ornan, “No, I insist on paying the full price. I will not take for the LORD what is yours, nor will I offer a burnt offering that costs me nothing.”
raw.note: David's principle of sacrificial giving, refusing to offer a costless sacrifice on Ornan's threshing floor.

raw.text: But Micaiah said, “As surely as the LORD lives, I will speak only what my God says.”
raw.note: The prophet Micaiah's declaration of unwavering fidelity to God's message, even in the face of royal pressure.

raw.text: Thus the work on the house of God in Jerusalem came to a standstill until the second year of the reign of Darius king of Persia.
raw.note: The historical record of the cessation of work on the second temple due to opposition.

raw.text: They refused to listen and failed to remember the wonders You performed among them. They became stiff-necked and in their rebellion appointed a leader to return to their slavery. But You are a forgiving God, gracious and compassionate, slow to anger and abounding in love. Therefore You did not forsake them,
raw.note: From the great prayer of confession, a summary of Israel's persistent rebellion contrasted with God's persistent grace.

raw.text: All the royal officials at the king’s gate bowed down and paid homage to Haman, for the king had commanded this concerning him. But Mordecai would not bow down or pay him homage.
raw.note: Mordecai's refusal to bow to Haman, the act of defiance that initiated the central conflict of the book.

raw.text: “Man, who is born of woman, is short of days and full of trouble.
raw.note: Job's poignant reflection on the brevity and difficulty of human life.

raw.text: My soul finds rest in God alone; my salvation comes from Him.
raw.note: A declaration of ultimate trust and rest found only in God.

raw.text: Behold, how good and pleasant it is when brothers dwell together in unity!
raw.note: A psalm of ascent celebrating the beauty and goodness of brotherly unity.

raw.text: Like a gold ring in a pig’s snout is a beautiful woman who shows no discretion.
raw.note: A vivid proverb illustrating that beauty without wisdom is incongruous and wasted.

raw.text: Whoever loves money never has money enough; whoever loves wealth is never satisfied with his income. This too is meaningless.
raw.note: The Preacher's observation on the insatiable and ultimately unsatisfying nature of materialism.

raw.text: Many waters cannot quench love; rivers cannot wash it away. If one were to give all the wealth of his house for love, it would be utterly scorned.
raw.note: A poetic declaration of the invincible and priceless nature of true love.

raw.text: The ox knows its owner, and the donkey its master’s manger, but Israel does not know; My people do not understand.”
raw.note: A lament contrasting the instinctual loyalty of animals with Israel's ignorance of their own God.

raw.text: Is there no balm in Gilead? Is there no physician there? Why then has the health of the daughter of my people not been restored?
raw.note: Jeremiah's sorrowful rhetorical question, lamenting the unhealed spiritual condition of his people.

raw.text: “Is it nothing to you, all you who pass by? Look and see! Is there any sorrow like my sorrow, which was brought upon me, which the LORD inflicted on the day of His fierce anger?”
raw.note: A personification of Jerusalem, crying out in her unique and unparalleled suffering.

raw.text: I will make your forehead like the hardest stone, harder than flint. Do not be afraid of them or terrified by them, though they are a rebellious house.”
raw.note: God's promise to give Ezekiel the resilience and fortitude needed to face a rebellious audience.

raw.text: But Daniel resolved not to defile himself with the royal food and wine, and he asked the chief official for permission not to defile himself this way.
raw.note: Daniel's personal commitment to remain faithful to God's law even in a foreign and compromising environment.

raw.text: And I will betroth you to Me forever; I will betroth you to Me in righteousness and justice, in loving devotion and compassion.
raw.note: A prophecy of the restoration of the covenant relationship, described in the intimate terms of a marriage betrothal.

raw.text: Blow the trumpet in Zion; sound the alarm on My holy mountain! Let all who live in the land tremble, for the day of the LORD is coming; surely it is near.
raw.note: A call to sound an alarm, signaling the imminent and terrifying arrival of the Day of the LORD.

raw.text: “Therefore this is what I will do to you, O Israel, and since I will do this to you, prepare to meet your God, O Israel!”
raw.note: A solemn and final warning to Israel to prepare for a direct encounter with God in judgment.

raw.text: “Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You pay tithes of mint, dill, and cumin, but you have neglected the more important matters of the law: justice, mercy, and faithfulness. You should have practiced the latter, without neglecting the former.
raw.note: Jesus's woe to the religious leaders, condemning their focus on minor regulations while neglecting core virtues.

raw.text: For they all gave out of their wealth; but she, out of her poverty, put in everything—all she had to live on.”
raw.note: Jesus's commentary on the widow's offering, highlighting that the value of a gift is measured by the sacrifice, not the amount.

raw.text: Then He said to them all, “If anyone wants to come after Me, he must deny himself and take up his cross daily and follow Me.
raw.note: Jesus's definition of the cost of discipleship: daily self-denial and identification with His suffering.

raw.text: Jesus wept.
raw.note: The shortest verse in the English Bible, powerfully demonstrating the humanity and compassion of Jesus.

raw.text: Then Agrippa said to Paul, “Do you think that in such a short time you can persuade me to be a Christian?”
raw.note: King Agrippa's reaction to Paul's testimony, acknowledging the persuasive power of his message.

raw.text: Everyone must submit himself to the governing authorities, for there is no authority except that which God has established. The authorities that exist have been established by God.
raw.note: An instruction on Christian civic duty, grounding the authority of government in God's sovereignty.

raw.text: So whether you eat or drink or whatever you do, do it all for the glory of God.
raw.note: A comprehensive principle for Christian living, that all activities should be oriented toward glorifying God.

raw.text: For we do not preach ourselves, but Jesus Christ as Lord, and ourselves as your servants for Jesus’ sake.
raw.note: Paul's summary of the apostolic message, emphasizing its Christ-centered, not self-centered, nature.

raw.text: For physical training is of some value, but godliness has value for all things, holding promise for both the present life and the life to come.
