raw.text: But you, keep your head in all situations, endure hardship, do the work of an evangelist, discharge all the duties of your ministry.
raw.note: Part of Paul's final charge to Timothy, outlining the key responsibilities of his ministry.

raw.text: Our people must learn to devote themselves to doing what is good, in order to provide for urgent needs and not be unproductive.
raw.note: An instruction for believers to be actively engaged in good works to meet needs.

raw.text: And do not forget to do good and to share with others, for with such sacrifices God is pleased.
raw.note: Defining good deeds and sharing as spiritual sacrifices that are pleasing to God.

raw.text: If anyone considers himself religious and yet does not bridle his tongue, he deceives his heart and his religion is worthless.
raw.note: A test of true religion: the ability to control one's speech.

raw.text: For Christ also suffered once for sins, the righteous for the unrighteous, to bring you to God. He was put to death in the body but made alive in the Spirit,
raw.note: A summary of Christ's substitutionary atonement and subsequent resurrection.

raw.text: We also have the prophetic message as something completely reliable, and you will do well to pay attention to it, as to a light shining in a dark place, until the day dawns and the morning star rises in your hearts.
raw.note: An affirmation of the reliability of Scripture, likening it to a light in the darkness.

raw.text: The one who does what is sinful is of the devil, because the devil has been sinning from the beginning. The reason the Son of God appeared was to destroy the devil’s work.
raw.note: A statement on the purpose of Christ's incarnation: to destroy the works of the devil.

raw.text: He who has an ear, let him hear what the Spirit says to the churches. To him who overcomes, I will give the right to eat from the tree of life, which is in the paradise of God.
raw.note: The promise to the overcomer in the church of Ephesus, a restoration of access to the tree of life.

raw.text: “Behold, I come like a thief! Blessed is he who stays awake and keeps his clothes with him, so that he may not go naked and be shamefully exposed.”
raw.note: A parenthetical warning from Christ during the description of the final judgments, urging spiritual readiness.

raw.text: The city does not need the sun or the moon to shine on it, for the glory of God gives it light, and the Lamb is its lamp.
raw.note: A description of the New Jerusalem, where the presence of God and the Lamb replaces the need for natural light.

raw.text: But the LORD God called to the man, “Where are you?”
raw.note: God's searching question to Adam after the fall, highlighting their broken fellowship.

raw.text: he stood at the entrance to the camp and said, “Whoever is for the LORD, come to me.” And all the Levites rallied to him.
raw.note: Moses's call for loyalty after the golden calf incident, to which the tribe of Levi responded.

raw.text: “See now that I myself am He! There is no god besides Me. I put to death and I bring to life, I have wounded and I will heal, and no one can deliver from My hand.
raw.note: From the Song of Moses, a powerful declaration of God's unique sovereignty over life, death, and deliverance.

raw.text: Some trust in chariots and some in horses, but we trust in the name of the LORD our God.
raw.note: A contrast between trusting in military might and trusting in the name of the LORD.

raw.text: Worship the LORD with gladness; come before Him with joyful songs.
raw.note: An instruction on the manner of worship: it should be characterized by joy and gladness.

raw.text: Where there is no vision, the people cast off restraint; but blessed is he who keeps the law.
raw.note: A proverb on the necessity of divine revelation for moral order.

raw.text: But your iniquities have separated you from your God; your sins have hidden His face from you, so that He will not hear.
raw.note: A clear statement that sin is the cause of separation between humanity and God.

raw.text: but let him who boasts boast in this, that he understands and knows Me, that I am the LORD, who exercises loving devotion, justice, and righteousness on the earth—for I delight in these things,” declares the LORD.
raw.note: Defining the only proper ground for boasting: a true, relational knowledge of God's character.

raw.text: just as the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give His life as a ransom for many.”
raw.note: Jesus's summary of His own mission, centered on service and sacrificial atonement.

raw.text: Peace I leave with you; My peace I give to you. I do not give to you as the world gives. Do not let your hearts be troubled and do not be afraid.
raw.note: Jesus's farewell gift to His disciples: a supernatural peace that is different from the world's.

raw.text: What then shall we say in response to these things? If God is for us, who can be against us?
raw.note: A rhetorical question expressing ultimate confidence and security based on God's alliance with believers.

raw.text: But thanks be to God, who gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ!
raw.note: A cry of thanksgiving for the victory over sin and death secured through Christ.

raw.text: made us alive with Christ even when we were dead in our trespasses. It is by grace you have been saved!
raw.note: A description of regeneration as a divine act of making the spiritually dead alive in Christ.

raw.text: Rejoice in the Lord always. I will say it again: Rejoice!
raw.note: A repeated command to find continuous joy in the Lord, irrespective of circumstances.

raw.text: But if we have food and clothing, we will be content with these.
raw.note: A principle of contentment based on meeting basic needs rather than accumulating wealth.

raw.text: All these people died in faith, without having received the things they were promised. However, they saw them and welcomed them from a distance. And they admitted that they were aliens and strangers on earth.
raw.note: A summary of the faith of the patriarchs, who died believing in promises they did not see fulfilled in their lifetime.

raw.text: But the one who looks intently into the perfect law that gives freedom, and continues to do this—not forgetting what he has heard, but doing it—he will be blessed in what he does.
raw.note: A description of the person who is blessed: one who actively and persistently engages with God's word.

raw.text: Beloved, I urge you as aliens and strangers in the world to abstain from sinful desires, which wage war against your soul.
raw.note: An exhortation based on the believer's identity as a foreigner in the world, calling for abstinence from fleshly desires.

raw.text: Then one of the elders said to me, “Do not weep! Behold, the Lion of the tribe of Judah, the Root of David, has triumphed. He is able to open the scroll and its seven seals.”
raw.note: The identification of the one worthy to open the scroll, using messianic titles for Christ.

raw.text: because Abraham obeyed My voice and kept My charge, My commandments, My statutes, and My laws.”
raw.note: God's affirmation to Isaac, grounding the covenant blessing in Abraham's prior obedience.

raw.text: But you are to select from all the people able men, God-fearing, trustworthy, and hating dishonest gain. Appoint them over the people as leaders of thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens.
raw.note: Jethro's counsel to Moses on delegating authority and establishing a judicial system.

raw.text: “Speak to the entire congregation of Israel and tell them: ‘Be holy, because I, the LORD your God, am holy.
raw.note: The foundational command of the Holiness Code, rooting the call to holiness in God's own character.

raw.text: But the LORD said to Moses, “Is the LORD’s arm too short? Now you will see whether or not My word comes true for you.”
raw.note: God's rhetorical question to Moses, affirming His unlimited power to provide for the people.

raw.text: For the LORD your God is the One who goes with you to fight for you against your enemies to give you victory.”
raw.note: An assurance to the Israelite army before battle, grounding their confidence in God's presence and power.

raw.text: But be very careful to keep the commandment and the law that Moses the servant of the LORD gave you: to love the LORD your God, to walk in all His ways, to keep His commandments, to hold fast to Him, and to serve Him with all your heart and with all your soul.”
raw.note: Joshua's parting charge to the tribes returning to the east of the Jordan.

raw.text: So they put away the foreign gods from among them and served the LORD. And He could no longer bear Israel’s misery.
raw.note: A poignant description of God's compassionate response to Israel's repentance.

raw.text: “Therefore the LORD, the God of Israel, declares: ‘I did indeed say that your house and the house of your father would walk before Me forever.’ But now the LORD declares: ‘Far be it from Me! For I will honor those who honor Me, but those who despise Me will be disdained.
raw.note: God's judgment on the house of Eli, establishing the principle that He honors those who honor Him.

raw.text: Is not my house right with God? For He has made with me an everlasting covenant, arranged and secured in every part. Surely He will not make all my salvation and every desire grow?
raw.note: From the last words of David, his confident reflection on the security of the Davidic Covenant.

raw.text: “Blessed be the LORD, who has given rest to His people Israel according to all that He promised. Not one word has failed of all the good promises He made through His servant Moses.
raw.note: Solomon's blessing at the temple dedication, affirming God's perfect faithfulness to His promises.

raw.text: But the LORD was gracious to them and had compassion on them, and He turned toward them because of His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. And to this day, He has been unwilling to destroy them or banish them from His presence.
raw.note: An explanation for Israel's preservation despite their sin, rooted in God's covenant faithfulness.

raw.text: David also said to his son Solomon, “Be strong and courageous, and do the work. Do not be afraid or discouraged, for the LORD God, my God, is with you. He will not fail you or forsake you until all the work for the service of the house of the LORD is finished.
raw.note: David's final charge to Solomon concerning the temple construction, echoing God's words to Joshua.

raw.text: He went out to meet Asa and said to him, “Listen to me, Asa and all Judah and Benjamin. The LORD is with you when you are with Him. If you seek Him, He will be found by you, but if you forsake Him, He will forsake you.
raw.note: The prophet Azariah's message to King Asa, outlining the conditional nature of God's manifest presence.

raw.text: For I was ashamed to ask the king for soldiers and horsemen to protect us from enemies on the road, because we had told the king, “The gracious hand of our God is on everyone who looks to Him, but His great anger is against all who forsake Him.”
raw.note: Ezra's reason for not requesting a military escort, choosing instead to demonstrate radical trust in God's protection.

raw.text: Wherever you hear the sound of the trumpet, join us there. Our God will fight for us!”
raw.note: Nehemiah's strategic instruction to the builders, combining human readiness with divine trust.

raw.text: The Spirit of God has made me, and the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
raw.note: Elihu's statement attributing his very existence and life to the creative work of God's Spirit.

raw.text: As for God, His way is perfect; the word of the LORD is flawless. He is a shield to all who take refuge in Him.
raw.note: A declaration of the perfection of God's character and the reliability of His word.

raw.text: Whom have I in heaven but You? And earth has nothing I desire besides You.
raw.note: The psalmist Asaph's climactic declaration of God's supreme value above all heavenly and earthly things.

raw.text: The horse is prepared for the day of battle, but victory belongs to the LORD.
raw.note: A proverb acknowledging the importance of human preparation while attributing the ultimate outcome to God's sovereignty.

raw.text: In the day of prosperity be joyful, but in the day of adversity consider this: God has made the one as well as the other, so that man cannot discover anything that will come after him.
raw.note: A wisdom saying encouraging appropriate responses to life's changing circumstances, recognizing God's sovereignty over both.

raw.text: “I, even I, am He who blots out your transgressions, for My own sake, and remembers your sins no more.
raw.note: God's declaration that He forgives sin not based on human merit, but for the sake of His own name and character.

raw.text: This is what the LORD says: “Cursed is the one who trusts in man, who depends on flesh for his strength and whose heart turns away from the LORD.
raw.note: A prophetic warning against placing ultimate trust in human strength and ability.

raw.text: I will search for the lost and bring back the strays. I will bind up the injured and strengthen the weak, but the sleek and the strong I will destroy. I will shepherd the flock with justice.
raw.note: God's description of His own pastoral care, contrasting His tender concern for the vulnerable with judgment for the arrogant.

raw.text: Now when Daniel learned that the document had been signed, he went into his house, where the windows of his upper room opened toward Jerusalem. Three times a day he got down on his knees and prayed, giving thanks to his God, just as he had done before.
raw.note: Daniel's act of faithful and consistent prayer, even in the face of a life-threatening decree.

raw.text: “Therefore everyone who hears these words of Mine and puts them into practice is like a wise man who built his house on the rock.
raw.note: The beginning of the parable of the wise and foolish builders, emphasizing obedience as the foundation for life.

raw.text: Therefore I tell you, whatever you ask in prayer, believe that you have received it, and it will be yours.
raw.note: Jesus's teaching on the importance of faith in the practice of prayer.

raw.text: For nothing will be impossible with God.”
raw.note: The angel Gabriel's response to Mary's question, affirming God's omnipotence.

raw.text: The Word became flesh and made His dwelling among us. We have seen His glory, the glory of the one and only Son from the Father, full of grace and truth.
raw.note: A cornerstone statement of the Incarnation: the eternal Word becoming human.

raw.text: They devoted themselves to the apostles’ teaching and to the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and to prayer.
raw.note: A summary of the four key practices that characterized the life of the very first church.

raw.text: For in the gospel a righteousness from God is revealed—a righteousness that is by faith from first to last, just as it is written: “The righteous will live by faith.”
raw.note: A key theological statement explaining that the righteousness required by God is also provided by God through faith.

raw.text: The natural man does not accept the things that come from the Spirit of God, for they are foolishness to him, and he cannot understand them, because they are spiritually discerned.
raw.note: A statement on the necessity of the Holy Spirit for understanding spiritual truths.

raw.text: For no matter how many promises God has made, they are “Yes” in Christ. And so through Him the “Amen” is spoken by us to the glory of God.
raw.note: A declaration that all of God's promises find their fulfillment and certainty in Jesus Christ.

raw.text: Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law by becoming a curse for us, for it is written: “Cursed is everyone who is hung on a tree.”
raw.note: An explanation of how Christ's death on the cross functioned as a substitutionary act to redeem believers from the law's curse.

raw.text: In Him we have redemption through His blood, the forgiveness of our trespasses, in accordance with the riches of His grace
raw.note: A concise summary of salvation, linking redemption and forgiveness to the blood of Christ and the grace of God.

raw.text: What is more, I consider everything a loss compared to the surpassing greatness of knowing Christ Jesus my Lord, for whose sake I have lost all things. I consider them rubbish, that I may gain Christ
raw.note: Paul's personal testimony of the supreme value of knowing Christ, compared to which all else is worthless.

raw.text: He has canceled the written code, with its regulations, that was against us and stood opposed to us; He has taken it away, nailing it to the cross.
raw.note: A powerful metaphor for how Christ's death satisfied and nullified the legal demands of the law that stood against humanity.

raw.text: For God did not appoint us to suffer wrath but to receive salvation through our Lord Jesus Christ.
raw.note: An assurance to believers that their destiny is salvation, not divine wrath.

raw.text: and to grant relief to you who are oppressed and to us as well. This will happen when the Lord Jesus is revealed from heaven in blazing fire with His powerful angels,
raw.note: A promise of future relief for the persecuted at the second coming of Christ.

raw.text: But you, O man of God, flee from these things and pursue righteousness, godliness, faith, love, perseverance, and gentleness.
raw.note: A two-part command to Timothy: to flee from sin and actively pursue Christian virtues.

raw.text: Guard the good deposit that was entrusted to you—guard it with the help of the Holy Spirit who lives in us.
raw.note: Paul's charge to Timothy to protect the gospel message that had been entrusted to him.

raw.text: It teaches us to say “No” to ungodliness and worldly passions, and to live self-controlled, upright, and godly lives in this present age,
raw.note: A description of the practical, sanctifying effect of God's grace.

raw.text: In fact, the law requires that nearly everything be cleansed with blood, and without the shedding of blood there is no forgiveness.
raw.note: A summary principle of the Old Testament sacrificial system, highlighting the necessity of blood for forgiveness.

raw.text: Every good and perfect gift is from above, coming down from the Father of the heavenly lights, who does not change like shifting shadows.
raw.note: A statement on the source of all good things and the unchanging nature of God.

raw.text: For you have been born again, not of perishable seed, but of imperishable, through the living and enduring word of God.
raw.note: A description of the new birth, emphasizing its divine and eternal source.

raw.text: The Lord is not slow to fulfill His promise as some understand slowness, but is patient with you, not wanting anyone to perish but everyone to come to repentance.
raw.note: An explanation for the apparent delay of Christ's return, attributing it to God's patience and desire for salvation.

raw.text: This is the message we have heard from Him and declare to you: God is light, and in Him there is no darkness at all.
raw.note: A foundational statement about the absolute moral purity and holiness of God's nature.

raw.text: And on His robe and on His thigh He has a name written: KING OF KINGS AND LORD OF LORDS.
raw.note: The title of the returning Christ, signifying His absolute sovereignty over all other rulers.

raw.text: Then I saw a new heaven and a new earth, for the first heaven and the first earth had passed away, and there was no longer any sea.
raw.note: John's vision of the final consummation of all things, the creation of a new heaven and earth.

raw.text: Then the LORD rained down burning sulfur on Sodom and Gomorrah—from the LORD out of the heavens.
raw.note: The divine judgment and destruction of the cities of the plain.

raw.text: And the sight of the glory of the LORD was like a consuming fire on the mountaintop in the eyes of the Israelites.
raw.note: A description of the appearance of God's glory on Mount Sinai.

raw.text: I delight to do Your will, O my God; Your law is within my heart.”
raw.note: A messianic psalm expressing the servant's deep desire and joy in doing God's will.

raw.text: As water reflects a face, so a man’s heart reflects the man.
raw.note: A proverb on the way that a person's heart or inner character is revealed in their life.

raw.text: “Come, all you who are thirsty, come to the waters; and you who have no money, come, buy and eat! Come, buy wine and milk without money and without cost.
raw.note: A gracious and universal invitation to come and receive spiritual satisfaction freely from God.

raw.text: “Ah, Lord GOD! You have made the heavens and the earth by Your great power and outstretched arm. Nothing is too hard for You.
raw.note: Jeremiah's prayer, affirming God's omnipotence as the Creator of all things.

raw.text: Do not be afraid of those who kill the body but cannot kill the soul. Rather, be afraid of the One who can destroy both soul and body in hell.
raw.note: Jesus's instruction on proper fear, directing it toward God rather than human opponents.

raw.text: So he got up and went to his father. But while he was still a long way off, his father saw him and was filled with compassion for him; he ran to his son, threw his arms around him and kissed him.
raw.note: The emotional climax of the Parable of the Prodigal Son, depicting the father's eager and compassionate welcome.

raw.text: Once again, Jesus spoke to the people and said, “I am the light of the world. Whoever follows Me will never walk in darkness, but will have the light of life.”
raw.note: One of Jesus's 'I Am' statements, identifying Himself as the exclusive source of spiritual light.

raw.text: “Men of Galilee,” they said, “why do you stand here looking into the sky? This same Jesus, who has been taken from you into heaven, will come back in the same way you have seen Him go into heaven.”
raw.note: The message of the angels to the disciples at the Ascension, promising Christ's personal and visible return.

raw.text: Therefore, I urge you, brothers, in view of God’s mercy, to offer your bodies as living sacrifices, holy and pleasing to God—this is your spiritual act of worship.
raw.note: A call for the total consecration of the believer's life as an act of spiritual worship.

raw.text: For as in Adam all die, so in Christ all will be made alive.
raw.note: A summary of federal theology, contrasting the universal death that comes through Adam with the universal life offered in Christ.

raw.text: Carry each other’s burdens, and in this way you will fulfill the law of Christ.
raw.note: An instruction on mutual support within the Christian community as the fulfillment of Christ's law.

raw.text: “In your anger do not sin”: Do not let the sun go down while you are still angry,
raw.note: An instruction on handling anger, permitting the emotion but forbidding sinful expression and urging quick resolution.

raw.text: Therefore, my beloved, just as you have always obeyed, not only in my presence, but now even more in my absence, continue to work out your salvation with fear and trembling.
raw.note: An exhortation for believers to actively pursue and live out the implications of their salvation.

raw.text: For there is one God and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus,
raw.note: A clear declaration of the unique role of Jesus Christ as the sole mediator between God and humanity.

raw.text: Therefore, since we have a great high priest who has passed through the heavens, Jesus the Son of God, let us hold firmly to what we profess.
raw.note: An encouragement to persevere in faith, based on the superiority of Jesus as our great high priest.

raw.text: You too, be patient and stand firm, because the Lord’s coming is near.
raw.note: An exhortation to patience and steadfastness, motivated by the nearness of Christ's return.

raw.text: Be shepherds of God’s flock that is under your care, serving as overseers—not because you must, but because you are willing, as God wants you to be; not greedy for money, but eager to serve;
raw.note: Instructions to church elders on the motives and manner of their pastoral oversight.

raw.text: After this I looked and there before me was a great multitude that no one could count, from every nation, tribe, people and language, standing before the throne and in front of the Lamb. They were wearing white robes and were holding palm branches in their hands.
raw.note: A vision of the redeemed from all over the world, a vast and diverse crowd worshiping God.

raw.text: Now the LORD was gracious to Sarah as He had said, and the LORD did for Sarah what He had promised.
raw.note: The fulfillment of God's long-awaited promise to Sarah in her old age.

raw.text: He said, “If you listen carefully to the voice of the LORD your God and do what is right in His eyes, if you pay attention to His commands and keep all His decrees, I will not bring on you any of the diseases I brought on the Egyptians, for I am the LORD, who heals you.”
raw.note: God reveals Himself as 'Yahweh-Rapha' (The LORD who heals), linking health to obedience.

raw.text: Yet in spite of this, when they are in the land of their enemies, I will not reject them or abhor them so as to destroy them completely, breaking My covenant with them. I am the LORD their God.
raw.note: A promise of God's enduring faithfulness to His covenant, even in the face of Israel's disobedience and exile.

raw.text: So Moses made a bronze snake and mounted it on a pole. If anyone who was bitten looked at the bronze snake, he would live.
raw.note: The account of the bronze serpent, a type of Christ that provided healing through looking in faith.

raw.text: It is a land the LORD your God cares for. The eyes of the LORD your God are continually on it from the beginning of the year to its end.
raw.note: A description of the Promised Land as being under God's constant care and supervision.

raw.text: All these kings and their lands Joshua conquered in one campaign, because the LORD, the God of Israel, fought for Israel.
raw.note: A summary of the southern conquest, attributing the swift victory to the LORD fighting for Israel.

raw.text: Then Samson said, “With a donkey’s jawbone I have made donkeys of them. With a donkey’s jawbone I have slain a thousand men.”
raw.note: Samson's poetic boast after defeating a thousand Philistines with an unconventional weapon.

raw.text: He who is the Glory of Israel does not lie or change His mind, for He is not a man, that He should change His mind.”
raw.note: Samuel's statement on the immutability of God, contrasting Him with fallible human beings.

raw.text: And David knew that the LORD had established him as king over Israel and had exalted his kingdom for the sake of His people Israel.
raw.note: David's recognition that his kingship was not for his own sake, but for the benefit of God's people.

raw.text: The ravens brought him bread and meat in the morning and bread and meat in the evening, and he drank from the brook.
raw.note: The miraculous provision for Elijah during the famine, being fed by ravens.

raw.text: For the Lord had caused the Aramean army to hear the sound of chariots and horses and a great army, so that they said to one another, “Look, the king of Israel has hired the Hittite and Egyptian kings to attack us!”
raw.note: God's miraculous deliverance of Samaria by causing the enemy army to hear a phantom army and flee.

raw.text: They were helped against them, and the Hagrites and all their allies were delivered into their hands, because they cried out to God in the battle. He answered their prayers because they trusted in Him.
raw.note: An account of a military victory attributed directly to prayer and trust in God during battle.

raw.text: He sought God during the days of Zechariah, who instructed him in the fear of God. And as long as he sought the LORD, God gave him success.
raw.note: A summary of King Uzziah's early reign, linking his seeking of God to his prosperity.

raw.text: But the eye of their God was on the elders of the Jews, so that they were not stopped until a report could go to Darius and his written reply be returned.
raw.note: A statement of divine providence, where God's watchful care protected the temple builders from their opponents.

raw.text: I also told them about the gracious hand of my God upon me and what the king had said to me. They replied, “Let us start rebuilding.” So they began this good work.
raw.note: Nehemiah's testimony to the people, inspiring them to join the work of rebuilding the walls.

raw.text: “I know that You can do all things and that no plan of Yours can be thwarted.
raw.note: Job's final confession, acknowledging the absolute sovereignty and omnipotence of God.

raw.text: The counsel of the LORD stands firm forever, the plans of His heart to all generations.
raw.note: A declaration of the eternal and unchanging nature of God's purposes.

raw.text: He will not let your foot slip; He who watches over you will not slumber.
raw.note: A promise of God's constant, vigilant care and protection.

raw.text: Blessed is the man who finds wisdom, the man who gains understanding,
raw.note: A beatitude on the happiness and value of acquiring wisdom and understanding.

raw.text: I know that everything God does will endure forever; nothing can be added to it and nothing taken from it. God does it so that men will fear Him.
raw.note: The Preacher's reflection on the permanence and perfection of God's work.

raw.text: No weapon forged against you will prevail, and you will refute every tongue that accuses you. This is the heritage of the servants of the LORD, and this is their vindication from Me,” declares the LORD.
raw.note: A promise of ultimate protection and vindication for the servants of God.

raw.text: “You have seen correctly,” said the LORD, “for I am watching to see that My word is fulfilled.”
raw.note: God's assurance to Jeremiah, based on the vision of the almond branch, that He is actively ensuring His word comes to pass.

raw.text: Therefore prophesy and say to them: ‘This is what the Lord GOD says: O My people, I will open your graves and bring you up from them; and I will bring you back to the land of Israel.
raw.note: The interpretation of the vision of dry bones, a promise of national restoration from the 'grave' of exile.

raw.text: If we are thrown into the blazing furnace, the God we serve is able to save us from it, and He will rescue us from your hand, O king.
raw.note: The first part of the three Hebrews' declaration of faith, affirming God's ability to save.

raw.text: Jesus looked at them and said, “With man this is impossible, but with God all things are possible.”
raw.note: Jesus's teaching on salvation, emphasizing that what is impossible for humans is possible for God.

raw.text: “Abba, Father,” He said, “everything is possible for You. Take this cup from Me. Yet not what I will, but what You will.”
raw.note: Jesus's intimate and submissive prayer in Gethsemane, using the Aramaic term 'Abba' for Father.

raw.text: For my eyes have seen Your salvation,
raw.note: From the Nunc Dimittis, Simeon's song of praise upon seeing the infant Jesus.

raw.text: Jesus answered, “You would have no authority over Me if it were not given to you from above. Therefore the one who handed Me over to you is guilty of a greater sin.”
raw.note: Jesus's statement to Pilate, affirming God's ultimate sovereignty even over his own trial.

raw.text: But Peter and the other apostles replied, “We must obey God rather than men!
raw.note: The apostles' declaration to the Sanhedrin, establishing the principle of ultimate allegiance to God.

raw.text: For from Him and through Him and to Him are all things. To Him be the glory forever! Amen.
raw.note: A doxology summarizing God's sovereign role in all of creation and history.

raw.text: For who makes you different from anyone else? What do you have that you did not receive? And if you did receive it, why do you boast as though you did not?
raw.note: A series of rhetorical questions rebuking arrogance, grounding all abilities and possessions in God's grace.

raw.text: For our boast is this: our conscience testifies that we have conducted ourselves in the world, and especially in our relations with you, in the holiness and sincerity that are from God—not in worldly wisdom, but in the grace of God.
raw.note: Paul's defense of his ministry, appealing to his clear conscience and sincere conduct.

raw.text: The entire law is fulfilled in a single decree: “Love your neighbor as yourself.”
raw.note: A summary of the Mosaic Law, showing that it is fulfilled in the command to love one's neighbor.

raw.text: In Him and through faith in Him we may approach God with freedom and confidence.
raw.note: A description of the believer's access to God, characterized by freedom and confidence through Christ.

raw.text: For it has been granted to you on behalf of Christ not only to believe in Him, but also to suffer for Him,
raw.note: A statement presenting both faith and suffering as gracious gifts given to the believer for Christ's sake.

raw.text: Devote yourselves to prayer, being watchful and thankful.
raw.note: An instruction on the manner of prayer, that it should be persistent, alert, and grateful.

raw.text: For this is the will of God, your sanctification: that you abstain from sexual immorality;
raw.note: A clear statement identifying personal holiness and sexual purity as God's will for believers.

raw.text: Now may the Lord of peace Himself give you peace at all times and in every way. The Lord be with all of you.
raw.note: A benediction praying for the comprehensive and constant peace that comes from the Lord.

raw.text: Now to the King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only God, be honor and glory forever and ever. Amen.
raw.note: A doxology ascribing honor and glory to God, described by His eternal and transcendent attributes.

raw.text: and which has now been revealed through the appearing of our Savior, Christ Jesus, who has abolished death and has brought life and immortality to light through the gospel.
raw.note: A summary of the effect of Christ's coming: the defeat of death and the revelation of immortal life.

raw.text: in the hope of eternal life, which God, who does not lie, promised before time began.
raw.note: A statement grounding Christian hope in the promise of the truthful, non-lying God.

raw.text: In the past God spoke to our fathers through the prophets at many times and in various ways,
raw.note: The opening of Hebrews, contrasting God's past revelation through prophets with His final revelation in the Son.

raw.text: because judgment without mercy will be shown to anyone who has not been merciful. Mercy triumphs over judgment!
raw.note: A principle of divine judgment, where the showing of mercy leads to receiving mercy.

raw.text: In this you greatly rejoice, though now for a little while you may have had to suffer grief in all kinds of trials.
raw.note: A description of the Christian experience, a mixture of present grief from trials and great joy in salvation.

raw.text: Simon Peter, a servant and apostle of Jesus Christ, To those who through the righteousness of our God and Savior Jesus Christ have received a faith as precious as ours:
raw.note: Peter's greeting, establishing the equal standing and value of the faith of all believers.

raw.text: Behold what manner of love the Father has given to us, that we should be called children of God!
raw.note: An expression of awe and wonder at the quality and greatness of God's love.

raw.text: The revelation of Jesus Christ, which God gave Him to show His servants what must soon take place. He made it known by sending His angel to His servant John,
raw.note: The opening verse of Revelation, defining the book's origin and purpose.

raw.text: There will be no more night. They will not need the light of a lamp or the light of the sun, for the Lord God will give them light. And they will reign forever and ever.
raw.note: A final description of the eternal state in the New Jerusalem, where God's presence eliminates all darkness.

raw.text: When Abram was ninety-nine years old, the LORD appeared to him and said, “I am God Almighty; walk before Me and be blameless.
raw.note: God's appearance to Abram, revealing Himself as 'El Shaddai' and calling him to a life of integrity.

raw.text: And you are to place the Urim and the Thummim in the breastpiece of judgment, so that they may be over Aaron’s heart whenever he enters the presence of the LORD. Thus Aaron will always bear the means of judgment for the Israelites over his heart before the LORD.
raw.note: The instruction for the Urim and Thummim, objects used by the high priest for discerning God's will.

raw.text: The sacrifices of God are a broken spirit; a broken and contrite heart, O God, You will not despise.
raw.note: A statement on the kind of sacrifice God truly desires: a spirit of humility and repentance.

raw.text: When words are many, sin is not absent, but he who holds his tongue is wise.
raw.note: A proverb on the danger of excessive talk and the wisdom of verbal restraint.

raw.text: Who has measured the waters in the hollow of his hand, or marked off the heavens with the span of his hand? Who has held the dust of the earth in a basket, or weighed the mountains on the scales and the hills in a balance?
raw.note: A series of rhetorical questions highlighting God's immeasurable power and wisdom as Creator.

raw.text: “For My people have committed two evils: They have forsaken Me, the spring of living water, and have dug their own cisterns, broken cisterns that cannot hold water.
raw.note: A powerful metaphor describing Israel's sin as abandoning the true source of life for inadequate, man-made substitutes.

raw.text: What good will it be for a man if he gains the whole world, yet forfeits his soul? Or what can a man give in exchange for his soul?
raw.note: Jesus's teaching on the supreme and incomparable value of the human soul.

raw.text: For everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, and the one who humbles himself will be exalted.”
raw.note: A principle of God's kingdom: a great reversal where humility leads to exaltation and pride leads to humiliation.

raw.text: Truly, truly, I tell you, unless a kernel of wheat falls to the ground and dies, it remains only a single seed. But if it dies, it produces many seeds.
raw.note: Jesus's agricultural metaphor to explain the necessity of His death for producing spiritual life.

raw.text: Through Him everyone who believes is justified from everything you could not be justified from by the law of Moses.
raw.note: Paul's sermon in Antioch, clearly distinguishing justification through Christ from the inability of the law to justify.

raw.text: Therefore, since we have been justified through faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ,
raw.note: The first result of justification by faith: peace with God.

raw.text: “Everything is permissible for me,” but not everything is beneficial. “Everything is permissible for me,” but I will not be mastered by anything.
raw.note: Paul's principle of Christian liberty, tempered by the considerations of benefit and mastery.

raw.text: For we live by faith, not by sight.
raw.note: A concise summary of the Christian's orientation to life, based on faith in unseen realities rather than visible circumstances.

raw.text: Therefore, as we have opportunity, let us do good to all people, especially to those who belong to the family of believers.
raw.note: An exhortation to do good universally, with a special priority for fellow believers.

raw.text: and walk in love, just as Christ loved us and gave Himself up for us as a fragrant offering and sacrifice to God.
raw.note: A command to walk in love, with Christ's self-sacrifice as the ultimate model and a pleasing offering to God.

raw.text: Therefore, my brothers, whom I love and long for, my joy and crown, stand firm in the Lord in this way, my beloved.
raw.note: Paul's affectionate appeal to the Philippians to remain steadfast in their faith.

raw.text: Let the peace of Christ rule in your hearts, since as members of one body you were called to peace. And be thankful.
raw.note: An instruction for the peace of Christ to act as the governing principle or 'umpire' in the believer's heart.

raw.text: Make sure that no one repays evil for evil. Always pursue what is good for one another and for all people.
raw.note: A command against retaliation, urging believers to proactively pursue good for everyone.

raw.text: Do not neglect to show hospitality to strangers, for by so doing some people have shown hospitality to angels without knowing it.
raw.note: An encouragement to practice hospitality, with a reference to the patriarchal narratives.

raw.text: We all stumble in many ways. If anyone is never at fault in what he says, he is a perfect man, able to control his whole body.
raw.note: A statement on the universality of human imperfection, highlighting control of the tongue as a mark of maturity.

raw.text: Each one should use whatever gift he has received to serve others, faithfully administering God’s grace in its various forms.
raw.note: An instruction for believers to act as good stewards of God's varied grace by using their gifts to serve.

raw.text: Those whom I love I rebuke and discipline. So be earnest and repent.
raw.note: Christ's explanation that His rebuke and discipline are motivated by love, calling for a zealous response.

raw.text: It was also called Mizpah, for he said, “May the LORD keep watch between you and me when we are out of each other’s sight.
raw.note: The naming of Mizpah, a covenantal landmark between Jacob and Laban, signifying God as a witness.

raw.text: And Moses built an altar and named it The LORD is my Banner.
raw.note: Moses names an altar 'Yahweh-Nissi' after a victory, declaring God as their banner of victory.

raw.text: “You must not go about as a slanderer among your people. You must not stand against the life of your neighbor. I am the LORD.
raw.note: A command from the Holiness Code against slander and endangering a neighbor's life.

raw.text: When a man makes a vow to the LORD or takes an oath to obligate himself by a pledge, he must not break his word; he must do everything he has said.
raw.note: A legal statute regarding the binding nature of vows and oaths made to the LORD.

raw.text: You must have accurate and honest weights and measures, so that you may live long in the land the LORD your God is giving you.
raw.note: A command for ethical business practices, linking honesty in commerce to longevity in the land.

raw.text: There was not a word of all that Moses had commanded that Joshua did not read before the whole assembly of Israel, including the women, the little ones, and the foreigners who lived among them.
raw.note: An account of the covenant renewal ceremony, emphasizing the inclusion of the entire community.

raw.text: From the heavens the stars fought; from their courses they fought against Sisera.
raw.note: From the Song of Deborah, a poetic description of cosmic or divine intervention in the battle.

raw.text: Even if someone rises to pursue you and seek your life, the life of my lord will be bound securely in the bundle of the living by the LORD your God. But the lives of your enemies He will hurl away as from the pocket of a sling.
raw.note: Abigail's wise appeal to David, using a metaphor of a securely bound bundle for his protected life.

raw.text: They also brought honey and curds, sheep, and cheese from cattle for David and his people to eat. For they said, “The people have become hungry and weary and thirsty in the wilderness.”
raw.note: The provision for David and his men during their flight from Absalom, an act of loyalty and kindness.

raw.text: I will surely do today what I swore to you by the LORD, the God of Israel: ‘Solomon your son shall be king after me, and he will sit on my throne in my place.’”
raw.note: David's confirmation of his oath to Bathsheba regarding Solomon's succession to the throne.

raw.text: So they went back and told Jehu, who said, “This is the word of the LORD, which He spoke through His servant Elijah the Tishbite: ‘On the plot of ground at Jezreel, dogs will devour the flesh of Jezebel.
raw.note: The fulfillment of Elijah's prophecy concerning the gruesome death of Queen Jezebel.

raw.text: David told the leaders of the Levites to appoint their brothers as singers to raise their voices with joy, accompanied by musical instruments—harps, lyres, and cymbals.
raw.note: David's organization of the Levitical musicians for the worship service when bringing the Ark to Jerusalem.

raw.text: “This is what Cyrus king of Persia says: ‘The LORD, the God of heaven, has given me all the kingdoms of the earth, and He has appointed me to build a temple for Him in Jerusalem of Judah. Whoever among you belongs to His people, may the LORD his God be with him, and let him go up.’”
raw.note: The decree of Cyrus, the final verse of Chronicles, ending the book on a note of hope and restoration.

raw.text: May God, who has caused His name to dwell there, overthrow any king or people who lifts a hand to alter this decree or to destroy this house of God in Jerusalem. I, Darius, have issued this decree. Let it be carried out with diligence.
raw.note: King Darius's decree supporting the temple rebuilding, including a curse on anyone who would interfere.

raw.text: But the former governors who preceded me had laid heavy burdens on the people, taking from them forty shekels of silver, in addition to food and wine. Their assistants also lorded it over the people. But because of my fear of God, I did not act this way.
raw.note: Nehemiah contrasting his own just leadership with the oppressive practices of his predecessors.

raw.text: So they hanged Haman on the gallows that he had prepared for Mordecai. Then the king’s fury subsided.
raw.note: The ironic and just execution of Haman on the very gallows he built for Mordecai.

raw.text: And after my skin has been thus destroyed, yet in my flesh I will see God.
raw.note: Job's declaration of faith in a future, bodily resurrection and the vision of God.

raw.text: Kiss the Son, lest He be angry and you perish in your way, for His wrath can flare up in a moment. Blessed are all who take refuge in Him.
raw.note: The concluding exhortation of a royal psalm, urging submission to the Son to avoid judgment.

raw.text: You have ascended on high; You have led captives away. You have received gifts from men, even from the rebellious, that the LORD God may dwell there.
raw.note: A psalm describing a triumphal procession, later applied by Paul to Christ's ascension.

raw.text: A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.
raw.note: A proverb defining the steadfast nature of true friendship and familial loyalty.

raw.text: “Meaningless! Meaningless!” says the Teacher. “Utterly meaningless! Everything is meaningless.”
raw.note: The opening thesis of Ecclesiastes, declaring the vanity of life 'under the sun' apart from God.

raw.text: How you have fallen from heaven, O morning star, son of the dawn! You have been cast down to the earth, you who once laid low the nations!
raw.note: A taunt song against the king of Babylon, often interpreted as a description of the fall of Satan.

raw.text: Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots? Neither can you do good who are accustomed to doing evil.
raw.note: A pair of rhetorical questions illustrating the ingrained and seemingly unchangeable nature of Judah's sin.

raw.text: Swarms of living creatures will live wherever the river flows. There will be large numbers of fish, because this water flows there and makes the salt water fresh; so where the river flows everything will live.
raw.note: From Ezekiel's vision of the temple, a description of the life-giving river that flows from it.

raw.text: And many who sleep in the dust of the earth will awake, some to everlasting life, but others to shame and everlasting contempt.
raw.note: One of the clearest Old Testament prophecies of a future, bodily resurrection to two different destinies.

raw.text: “Where is the one who has been born king of the Jews? We saw his star in the east and have come to worship him.”
raw.note: The inquiry of the Magi, who were guided by a star to find the newborn king.

raw.text: The beginning of the gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God.
raw.note: The opening verse and title of Mark's gospel account.

raw.text: “I tell you,” He answered, “if they remain silent, the very stones will cry out.”
raw.note: Jesus's response to the Pharisees during the Triumphal Entry, indicating that creation itself would praise Him if people were silent.

raw.text: And he brought him to Jesus. Jesus looked at him and said, “You are Simon son of John. You will be called Cephas” (which, when translated, is Peter).
raw.note: Jesus renaming Simon to Peter (Cephas), signifying his future role.

raw.text: The voice spoke to him a second time: “Do not call anything impure that God has made clean.”
raw.note: The divine instruction to Peter in his vision, preparing him to take the gospel to the Gentiles.

raw.text: The God of peace will soon crush Satan under your feet. The grace of our Lord Jesus be with you.
raw.note: A promise of final victory over Satan, given as an encouragement to the Roman church.

raw.text: For the foolishness of God is wiser than man’s wisdom, and the weakness of God is stronger than man’s strength.
raw.note: A paradoxical statement highlighting the superiority of God's ways, which appear foolish to the world.

raw.text: For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that though He was rich, yet for your sakes He became poor, so that you through His poverty might become rich.
raw.note: A summary of the incarnation and atonement, described in terms of Christ's voluntary poverty for our enrichment.

raw.text: who gave Himself for our sins to rescue us from the present evil age, according to the will of our God and Father,
raw.note: A concise statement of the purpose of Christ's self-sacrifice: deliverance from the present evil age.

raw.text: And take the helmet of salvation and the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God.
raw.note: The final two pieces of the Armor of God: one defensive (salvation) and one offensive (the word of God).

raw.text: If you have any encouragement from being united with Christ, if any comfort from His love, if any fellowship with the Spirit, if any tenderness and compassion,
raw.note: The beginning of Paul's appeal for unity, grounding it in the shared spiritual experiences of believers.

raw.text: We proclaim Him, admonishing and teaching everyone with all wisdom, so that we may present everyone perfect in Christ.
raw.note: A summary of the apostolic ministry's method and goal: to present every believer mature in Christ.

raw.text: On the contrary, we speak as men approved by God to be entrusted with the gospel. We are not trying to please men, but God, who tests our hearts.
raw.note: Paul's description of his motivation in ministry: to please God who has approved and entrusted him.

raw.text: But the Lord is faithful, and He will strengthen you and protect you from the evil one.
raw.note: An assurance of God's faithfulness to strengthen and guard believers.

raw.text: An overseer, then, must be above reproach, the husband of one wife, temperate, self-controlled, respectable, hospitable, able to teach,
raw.note: The beginning of the list of qualifications for a church overseer (elder).

raw.text: You therefore, my child, be strong in the grace that is in Christ Jesus.
raw.note: Paul's exhortation to Timothy to find his strength not in himself, but in the grace of Christ.

raw.text: Remind the people to be subject to rulers and authorities, to be obedient, to be ready for every good work,
raw.note: An instruction for pastoral ministry, emphasizing the need to teach civic responsibility.

raw.text: Let us not neglect our meeting together, as some have made a habit, but let us encourage one another, and all the more as you see the Day approaching.
raw.note: A command against forsaking corporate worship, especially in light of the approaching Day of the Lord.

raw.text: Consider it pure joy, my brothers, whenever you face trials of many kinds,
raw.note: The paradoxical instruction to view trials not with dread, but with joy.

raw.text: Like newborn babies, crave pure spiritual milk, so that by it you may grow up in your salvation,
raw.note: A metaphor urging new believers to have a strong desire for spiritual nourishment for growth.

raw.text: For no prophecy was ever produced by the will of man, but men spoke from God as they were carried along by the Holy Spirit.
raw.note: A key verse on the doctrine of divine inspiration, describing the Holy Spirit's role in prophecy.

raw.text: This is love: not that we loved God, but that He loved us and sent His Son as an atoning sacrifice for our sins.
raw.note: A definition of true love, locating its origin in God's initiative and Christ's atoning work.

raw.text: Then I saw heaven standing open, and there before me was a white horse. And its rider is called Faithful and True. With justice He judges and wages war.
raw.note: The vision of the returning Christ as a righteous warrior king.

raw.text: Then the angel showed me the river of the water of life, as clear as crystal, flowing from the throne of God and of the Lamb
raw.note: A description of the river of life in the New Jerusalem, symbolizing eternal life flowing from God.

raw.text: But God sent me ahead of you to preserve for you a remnant on earth and to save your lives by a great deliverance.
raw.note: Joseph's theological interpretation of his own story, seeing God's providential hand in his suffering.

raw.text: “I will surely be with you,” God said, “and this will be the sign to you that I have sent you: When you have brought the people out of Egypt, you will worship God on this mountain.”
raw.note: God's sign to Moses to confirm his call: a future event of worship at the very place of the call.

raw.text: Even though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil, for You are with me; Your rod and Your staff, they comfort me.
raw.note: A declaration of trust in God's protective and comforting presence even in the darkest and most dangerous situations.

raw.text: The lot is cast into the lap, but its every decision is from the LORD.
raw.note: A proverb on God's absolute sovereignty, extending even to what appears to be random chance.

raw.text: The grass withers and the flowers fall, but the word of our God stands forever.
raw.note: A contrast between the transient nature of the physical world and the eternal permanence of God's word.

raw.text: Then the LORD reached out His hand and touched my mouth and said to me, “Behold, I have put My words in your mouth.
raw.note: A symbolic act in Jeremiah's commissioning, signifying the divine origin of his message.

raw.text: For My yoke is easy and My burden is light.”
raw.note: Jesus's description of the life of discipleship, contrasting it with the heavy burdens of other religious systems.

raw.text: to shine on those living in darkness and in the shadow of death, to guide our feet into the path of peace.”
raw.note: From Zechariah's prophecy, describing the mission of the Messiah to bring light, guidance, and peace.

raw.text: I give them eternal life, and they will never perish. No one can snatch them out of My hand.
raw.note: A promise of the absolute security of the believer in Christ's hand.

raw.text: For He has set a day when He will judge the world with justice by the Man He has appointed. He has given proof of this to all men by raising Him from the dead.”
raw.note: Paul's sermon in Athens, presenting the resurrection as the proof of a future, universal judgment.

raw.text: I consider that our present sufferings are not worth comparing with the glory that will be revealed in us.
raw.note: A statement of perspective, weighing present suffering against the immeasurable greatness of future glory.

raw.text: Now we see but a poor reflection as in a mirror; then we shall see face to face. Now I know in part; then I shall know fully, even as I am fully known.
raw.note: A contrast between the partial, indirect knowledge of God in this life and the direct, complete knowledge in the life to come.

raw.text: So you are no longer a slave, but a son; and since you are a son, God has made you also an heir.
raw.note: A declaration of the believer's change in status from slavery to sonship and heirship.

raw.text: And you also were included in Christ when you heard the word of truth, the gospel of your salvation. Having believed, you were marked in Him with a seal, the promised Holy Spirit,
raw.note: A description of the Holy Spirit as the seal of God's ownership and the guarantee of the believer's salvation.

raw.text: I want to know Christ and the power of His resurrection and the fellowship of His sufferings, being conformed to Him in His death,
raw.note: Paul's ultimate spiritual ambition: a deep, experiential knowledge of Christ in His power and suffering.

raw.text: And having disarmed the powers and authorities, He made a public spectacle of them, triumphing over them by the cross.
raw.note: A depiction of the cross not as a defeat, but as a triumphant victory over spiritual powers.

raw.text: Watch your life and doctrine closely. Persevere in them, because if you do, you will save both yourself and your hearers.
raw.note: A charge to Timothy to pay close attention to both his personal conduct and his teaching.

raw.text: Unlike the other high priests, He does not need to offer sacrifices day after day, first for His own sins, and then for the sins of the people. He sacrificed for their sins once for all when He offered Himself.
raw.note: A contrast between the repetitive sacrifices of the Levitical priests and Christ's single, sufficient sacrifice.

raw.text: But when he asks, he must believe and not doubt, because he who doubts is like a wave of the sea, blown and tossed by the wind.
raw.note: An instruction on prayer, warning that a doubting mind is unstable and hinders receiving from God.

raw.text: Do not repay evil with evil or insult with insult, but with blessing, because to this you were called so that you may inherit a blessing.
raw.note: A command to respond to evil with blessing, linking this action to the believer's own calling and inheritance.

raw.text: They will make war against the Lamb, but the Lamb will overcome them because He is Lord of lords and King of kings—and with Him will be His called, chosen, and faithful followers.”
raw.note: A prophecy of the final conflict and the certain victory of the Lamb and His followers.

raw.text: No one in this house is greater than I am. My master has withheld nothing from me except you, because you are his wife. How then could I do such a wicked thing and sin against God?”
raw.note: Joseph's response to Potiphar's wife, demonstrating his integrity and fear of God.

raw.text: you are to say, ‘It is the Passover sacrifice to the LORD, who passed over the houses of the Israelites in Egypt when He struck down the Egyptians and spared our homes.’” Then the people bowed down and worshiped.
raw.note: The instruction for the Passover observance, explaining its meaning as a memorial of God's deliverance.

raw.text: “You must not hate your brother in your heart. Rebuke your neighbor directly, so you will not share in his guilt.
raw.note: A command from the Holiness Code that promotes direct and honest confrontation over hidden resentment.

raw.text: How can I curse those whom God has not cursed? How can I denounce those whom the LORD has not denounced?
raw.note: From Balaam's oracle, his inability to curse Israel because God has blessed them.

raw.text: When such a person hears the words of this oath, he invokes a blessing on himself, thinking, “I will be safe, even though I persist in my own way.” This will bring disaster on the watered land as well as the dry.
raw.note: A warning against false security and self-deception for those who hear but disregard the covenant oath.

raw.text: “Now therefore, fear the LORD and serve Him in sincerity and in truth. Get rid of the gods your fathers served beyond the River and in Egypt, and serve the LORD.
raw.note: Joshua's charge to the people at the Shechem covenant renewal, calling for sincere and exclusive worship.

raw.text: “But Lord,” Gideon replied, “how can I save Israel? Indeed, my clan is the weakest in Manasseh, and I am the youngest in my father’s house.”
raw.note: Gideon's humble and insecure response to the divine call, highlighting his perceived inadequacy.

raw.text: The LORD who delivered me from the paw of the lion and the paw of the bear will deliver me from the hand of this Philistine.” Saul said to David, “Go, and the LORD be with you.”
raw.note: David's testimony of God's past faithfulness as the basis for his confidence in facing Goliath.

raw.text: Then David said to Abishai and all his servants, “Behold, my own son, my own flesh and blood, is trying to take my life. How much more, then, this Benjamite! Leave him alone and let him curse, for the LORD has told him to.
raw.note: David's response to Shimei's cursing, interpreting it with humility as potentially being from the LORD.

raw.text: When all Israel heard the verdict the king had given, they held the king in awe, because they saw that he had wisdom from God to administer justice.
raw.note: The people's reaction to Solomon's wise judgment in the case of the two prostitutes, recognizing its divine origin.

raw.text: Now Naaman was commander of the army of the king of Aram. He was a great man in the sight of his master and highly regarded, because through him the LORD had given victory to Aram. He was a valiant soldier, but he had leprosy.
raw.note: The introduction to Naaman, a powerful and respected man afflicted with a dreaded disease.

raw.text: Wealth and honor come from You; You are the ruler of all things. In Your hands are strength and power to exalt and give strength to all.
raw.note: From David's prayer, an acknowledgement that all wealth, honor, and strength originate from God.

raw.text: And when he prayed to Him, the LORD was moved by his entreaty and listened to his plea. So He brought him back to Jerusalem and to his kingdom. Then Manasseh knew that the LORD is God.
raw.note: The account of the repentance and restoration of Manasseh, one of Judah's most wicked kings.

raw.text: The people could not distinguish the sound of the shouts of joy from the sound of weeping, because the people made so much noise. And the sound was heard far away.
raw.note: The mixed emotions of the people at the laying of the second temple's foundation: joy for the new beginning and weeping in memory of the former temple's glory.

raw.text: When all our enemies heard about this, all the surrounding nations were afraid and lost their self-confidence, because they realized that this work had been done with the help of our God.
raw.note: The reaction of the enemies upon the completion of Jerusalem's wall, recognizing it as a divinely aided accomplishment.

raw.text: On the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, the month of Adar, the king’s command and edict were to be carried out. On this day the enemies of the Jews had hoped to overpower them, but now the tables were turned and the Jews got the upper hand over those who hated them.
raw.note: The great reversal of Purim, where the intended day of destruction for the Jews became their day of victory.

raw.text: In all this, Job did not sin by charging God with wrongdoing.
raw.note: The summary of Job's initial response to his calamities, highlighting his refusal to blame God.

raw.text: May the words of my mouth and the meditation of my heart be pleasing in Your sight, O LORD, my Rock and my Redeemer.
raw.note: A prayer for the acceptability of one's inner thoughts and outward speech to God.

raw.text: He who dwells in the shelter of the Most High will abide in the shadow of the Almighty.
raw.note: A promise of divine protection and security for those who live in close fellowship with God.

raw.text: Above all else, guard your heart, for it is the wellspring of life.
raw.note: A key proverb on the importance of guarding one's inner self, as it determines the course of life.

raw.text: Do not answer a fool according to his folly, or you will be like him yourself.
raw.note: Wisdom on how to engage with a foolish person, advising against descending to their level.

raw.text: For with much wisdom comes much sorrow, and with more knowledge comes more grief.
raw.note: The Preacher's observation that increased wisdom and knowledge can lead to a greater awareness of life's pain and futility.

raw.text: A voice of one calling: “In the wilderness prepare the way for the LORD; make straight in the desert a highway for our God.
