raw.note: A famous depiction of Jesus seeking fellowship with individuals.

raw.text: And not only that, but we also rejoice in our sufferings, because we know that suffering produces perseverance;
raw.note: Connects suffering with the development of perseverance.

raw.text: In the same way, the Spirit helps us in our weakness. For we do not know what to pray for as we ought, but the Spirit Himself intercedes for us with groanings too deep for words.
raw.note: Describes the Holy Spirit's role in interceding for believers.

raw.text: to redeem those under the law, that we might receive our adoption as sons.
raw.note: Explains redemption's purpose as adoption into God's family.

raw.text: Furthermore, it is required of stewards that they be found faithful.
raw.note: A key principle of stewardship is faithfulness.

raw.text: Be completely humble and gentle; be patient, bearing with one another in love.
raw.note: A call to humility, patience, and mutual forbearance.

raw.text: Bear with each other and forgive any complaint you may have against one another. Forgive as the Lord forgave you.
raw.note: Commands mutual forgiveness, modeled on Christ's forgiveness.

raw.text: Give thanks in all circumstances, for this is God’s will for you in Christ Jesus.
raw.note: Instructs believers to be thankful in all circumstances.

raw.text: But when you pray, go into your inner room, shut your door, and pray to your Father, who is unseen. And your Father, who sees what is done in secret, will reward you.
raw.note: Jesus's teaching on private prayer.

raw.text: And wherever He went—into villages, towns, or countryside—they laid the sick in the marketplaces and begged Him to let them touch even the tassel of His cloak. And all who touched Him were healed.
raw.note: Describes the widespread healing ministry of Jesus.

raw.text: He replied, “Whether He is a sinner I do not know. One thing I do know: I was blind, but now I see!”
raw.note: The simple and powerful testimony of the man born blind.

raw.text: While they were stoning him, Stephen prayed, “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.”
raw.note: The martyrdom of Stephen, the first Christian martyr.

raw.text: The Spirit clearly says that in later times some will abandon the faith and follow deceiving spirits and things taught by demons.
raw.note: A prophecy about apostasy in the latter times.

raw.text: But there were also false prophets among the people, just as there will be false teachers among you. They will secretly introduce destructive heresies, even denying the Master who bought them—bringing swift destruction on themselves.
raw.note: A warning against false teachers and destructive heresies.

raw.text: Beloved, although I was very eager to write to you about our common salvation, I found it necessary to write to you urging you to contend for the faith that was once for all entrusted to the saints.
raw.note: An exhortation to defend the orthodox Christian faith.

raw.text: in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet. For the trumpet will sound, the dead will be raised imperishable, and we will be changed.
raw.note: Describes the instantaneous nature of the resurrection at the last trumpet.

raw.text: Blessed and holy are those who share in the first resurrection. The second death has no power over them, but they will be priests of God and of Christ, and will reign with Him for a thousand years.
raw.note: The blessing of participating in the first resurrection and reigning for a millennium.

raw.text: For at that time there will be great tribulation, unequaled from the beginning of the world until now, and never to be equaled again.
raw.note: Jesus's prophecy of a time of unprecedented great tribulation.

raw.text: Let no one deceive you in any way, for that day will not come until the rebellion occurs and the man of lawlessness is revealed, the man doomed to destruction.
raw.note: A prophecy concerning the 'man of sin' who will be revealed before the end.

raw.text: He who testifies to these things says, “Yes, I am coming soon.” Amen. Come, Lord Jesus!
raw.note: The final prayer of the Bible, anticipating Jesus's swift return.

raw.text: And those He predestined, He also called; those He called, He also justified; those He justified, He also glorified.
raw.note: The 'golden chain of salvation', linking predestination to glorification.

raw.text: But if serving the LORD seems undesirable to you, then choose for yourselves this day whom you will serve, whether the gods your fathers served beyond the River, or the gods of the Amorites, in whose land you are living. But as for me and my household, we will serve the LORD.”
raw.note: Joshua's famous declaration of commitment to serve the LORD.

raw.text: Above all, you must understand that no prophecy of Scripture comes from one’s own interpretation.
raw.note: A principle of biblical interpretation regarding prophecy.

raw.text: The heavens declare the glory of God; the skies proclaim the work of His hands.
raw.note: A psalm celebrating God's glory as revealed in creation.

raw.text: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge, but fools despise wisdom and instruction.
raw.note: A foundational proverb on the starting point of true knowledge.

raw.text: “For My thoughts are not your thoughts, neither are your ways My ways,” declares the LORD.
raw.note: A declaration of the transcendent nature of God's thoughts and ways.

raw.text: And you shall love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your mind and with all your strength.’
raw.note: Jesus's statement of the greatest commandment.

raw.text: Do to others as you would have them do to you.
raw.note: The Golden Rule, a core ethical teaching of Jesus.

raw.text: Greater love has no one than this, that he lay down his life for his friends.
raw.note: Jesus's definition of the ultimate expression of love.

raw.text: ‘For in Him we live and move and have our being.’ As some of your own poets have said, ‘We are His offspring.’
raw.note: Paul's sermon in Athens, quoting Greek poets to illustrate humanity's dependence on God.

raw.text: Do you not know that your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit who is in you, whom you have received from God? You are not your own;
raw.note: The believer's body is described as a temple of the Holy Spirit.

raw.text: There is neither Jew nor Greek, slave nor free, male nor female, for you are all one in Christ Jesus.
raw.note: A radical statement of unity and equality in Christ.

raw.text: Husbands, love your wives, just as Christ loved the church and gave Himself up for her
raw.note: An instruction for husbands, using Christ's love for the church as the model.

raw.text: Do nothing out of selfish ambition or empty conceit, but in humility consider others more important than yourselves.
raw.note: A call to selfless humility, putting others first.

raw.text: Whatever you do, work at it with all your heart, as working for the Lord, not for men,
raw.note: An exhortation to work with wholehearted devotion as if for the Lord.

raw.text: For there is one God and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus,
raw.note: A clear statement on the singular mediation of Christ.

raw.text: Just as man is appointed to die once, and after that to face judgment,
raw.note: A statement on the certainty of death and subsequent judgment.

raw.text: Be doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving yourselves.
raw.note: Emphasizes the importance of applying, not just hearing, God's word.

raw.text: But in your hearts sanctify Christ as Lord. Always be prepared to give an answer to everyone who asks you to give the reason for the hope that you have. But do this with gentleness and respect,
raw.note: A call to be prepared to defend the Christian hope.

raw.text: If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.
raw.note: The promise of forgiveness and cleansing upon confession of sins.

raw.text: “You are worthy, our Lord and God, to receive glory and honor and power, for You created all things, and by Your will they were created and have their being.”
raw.note: The song of the 24 elders, worshiping God as the worthy Creator.

raw.text: Now the LORD said to Abram, “Go from your country, your people, and your father’s household to the land I will show you.
raw.note: The call of Abram, the beginning of the patriarchal narrative.

raw.text: The LORD will fight for you; you need only to be still.”
raw.note: Moses's assurance to the Israelites at the Red Sea.

raw.text: Do not seek revenge or bear a grudge against any of your people, but love your neighbor as yourself. I am the LORD.
raw.note: The command to love one's neighbor as oneself.

raw.text: God is not a man, that He should lie, nor a son of man, that He should change His mind. Does He speak and then not act? Does He promise and not fulfill?
raw.note: Balaam's prophecy about the unchangeable and truthful nature of God.

raw.text: Hear, O Israel: The LORD our God, the LORD is one.
raw.note: The Shema, the foundational statement of Jewish monotheism.

raw.text: This Book of the Law must not depart from your mouth; meditate on it day and night, so that you may be careful to do everything written in it. For then you will prosper and succeed.
raw.note: God's instruction to Joshua on the importance of meditating on His law.

raw.text: May the LORD repay your work, and may you be richly rewarded by the LORD, the God of Israel, under whose wings you have come to take refuge.”
raw.note: Boaz's blessing upon Ruth for her faithfulness.

raw.text: But Samuel replied, “Does the LORD delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices as much as in obeying the voice of the LORD? Behold, obedience is better than sacrifice, and attentiveness is better than the fat of rams.
raw.note: Samuel's rebuke of Saul, emphasizing obedience over ritual sacrifice.

raw.text: As for God, His way is perfect; the word of the LORD is flawless. He is a shield to all who take refuge in Him.
raw.note: David's song of praise for God's perfect way and protection.

raw.text: “But will God indeed dwell on earth? Behold, the heavens, even the highest heavens, cannot contain You; how much less this temple I have built!
raw.note: Solomon's prayer at the dedication of the temple, acknowledging God's transcendence.

raw.text: Then Joseph remembered his dreams about them and said to them, “You are spies! You have come to see where our land is unprotected.”
raw.note: Joseph accusing his brothers, setting in motion the test of their character.

raw.text: eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,
raw.note: A foundational principle of retributive justice in the Mosaic Law, known as 'lex talionis'.

raw.text: The goat will carry on itself all their iniquities to a solitary place, and the man shall release it in the wilderness.
raw.note: The description of the scapegoat on the Day of Atonement, symbolically carrying away the sins of the people.

raw.text: But Balaam said to Balak, “See, I have come to you. But can I say just anything? I must speak only the word that God puts in my mouth.”
raw.note: Balaam's statement to King Balak, acknowledging his constraint to speak only God's message.

raw.text: It is to be with him, and he is to read it all the days of his life, so that he may learn to revere the LORD his God and follow carefully all the words of this law and these decrees
raw.note: The requirement for the king of Israel to constantly read and study the Law of God.

raw.text: Then Joshua son of Nun secretly sent two spies from Shittim. “Go, look over the land,” he said, “especially Jericho.” So they went and entered the house of a prostitute named Rahab and stayed there.
raw.note: The beginning of the Jericho reconnaissance mission, introducing the key character Rahab.

raw.text: “I will certainly go with you,” said Deborah. “But because of the way you are going about this, the honor will not be yours, for the LORD will deliver Sisera into the hands of a woman.”
raw.note: Deborah's prophecy to Barak, foretelling that the glory of victory would go to a woman.

raw.text: Samuel said to Saul, “Why have you disturbed me by bringing me up?” “I am in great distress,” Saul said. “The Philistines are fighting against me, and God has turned away from me. He no longer answers me, either by prophets or by dreams. So I have called on you to tell me what to do.”
raw.note: The confrontation between the spirit of Samuel and King Saul at Endor.

raw.text: Then Nathan said to David, “You are the man! This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: ‘I anointed you king over Israel, and I delivered you from the hand of Saul.
raw.note: The prophet Nathan's direct and courageous confrontation of King David after his sin with Bathsheba.

raw.text: When King Jeroboam heard the word that the man of God cried out against the altar at Bethel, he stretched out his hand from the altar and said, “Seize him!” But the hand he stretched out toward the man shriveled up, so that he could not pull it back.
raw.note: A miraculous judgment on King Jeroboam for trying to harm the man of God.

raw.text: In those days Hezekiah became ill and was at the point of death. The prophet Isaiah son of Amoz went to him and said, “This is what the LORD says: Put your house in order, because you are going to die; you will not recover.”
raw.note: The initial grim prognosis given to King Hezekiah by the prophet Isaiah.

raw.text: Then Satan rose up against Israel and incited David to take a census of Israel.
raw.note: The account of David's sinful census, attributed here to the incitement of Satan.

raw.text: But when envoys were sent by the rulers of Babylon to ask him about the miraculous sign that had occurred in the land, God left him to test him and to know everything that was in his heart.
raw.note: An explanation for Hezekiah's failure, that God tested him to reveal the pride in his heart.

raw.text: And you, Ezra, in accordance with the wisdom of your God, which you possess, are to appoint magistrates and judges to administer justice for all the people of Trans-Euphrates—all who know the laws of your God. And you are to teach any who do not know them.
raw.note: The commission given to Ezra by King Artaxerxes to establish a judicial and educational system based on God's law.

raw.text: When I heard these things, I sat down and wept. For some days I mourned and fasted and prayed before the God of heaven.
raw.note: Nehemiah's immediate and heartfelt response of grief and prayer upon hearing of Jerusalem's condition.

raw.text: When Mordecai learned of all that had been done, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth and ashes, and went out into the city, wailing loudly and bitterly.
raw.note: The traditional signs of deep mourning and distress displayed by Mordecai.

raw.text: So Satan went out from the presence of the LORD and afflicted Job with painful sores from the soles of his feet to the crown of his head.
raw.note: The second test of Job, involving severe physical affliction.

raw.text: In peace I will lie down and sleep, for You alone, O LORD, make me dwell in safety.
raw.note: A declaration of peaceful rest based on the security found only in the LORD.

raw.text: He split the rocks in the wilderness and gave them water as abundant as the seas;
raw.note: A poetic recounting of God's miraculous provision of water from a rock in the desert.

raw.text: “The LORD possessed me at the beginning of His work, before His deeds of old.
raw.note: From the poem on wisdom, a personification of wisdom describing her existence with God before creation.

raw.text: If your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat; if he is thirsty, give him water to drink.
raw.note: A wisdom saying commanding proactive kindness toward one's enemies.

raw.text: A good name is better than fine perfume, and the day of death better than the day of birth.
raw.note: A paradoxical proverb from the Teacher, valuing reputation over luxury and the end of life over its beginning.

raw.text: Learn to do right; seek justice. Defend the oppressed. Take up the cause of the fatherless; plead the case of the widow.
raw.note: A call to practical righteousness, defined by active pursuit of social justice for the vulnerable.

raw.text: This is what the LORD says: “A voice is heard in Ramah, mourning and great weeping, Rachel weeping for her children and refusing to be comforted, because they are no more.”
raw.note: A prophecy of the grief of the exile, later applied by Matthew to the slaughter of the infants in Bethlehem.

raw.text: And I went to the exiles at Tel-abib who lived by the Kebar River. And there, where they were living, I sat among them for seven days, overwhelmed.
raw.note: Ezekiel's initial reaction to his prophetic call and the condition of the exiles, sitting in stunned silence.

raw.text: Suddenly the fingers of a human hand appeared and wrote on the plaster of the wall, near the lampstand in the royal palace. The king watched the hand as it wrote.
raw.note: The terrifying appearance of the disembodied hand that wrote the message of judgment on the wall.

raw.text: When they had gone, an angel of the Lord appeared to Joseph in a dream. “Get up,” he said, “take the child and his mother and escape to Egypt. Stay there until I tell you, for Herod is going to search for the child to kill him.”
raw.note: The angelic warning to Joseph, prompting the flight to Egypt to escape Herod's persecution.

raw.text: Then Jesus asked him, “What is your name?” “My name is Legion,” he replied, “for we are many.”
raw.note: The self-identification of the demons possessing the man from the Gerasenes, indicating a massive infestation.

raw.text: But a Samaritan, as he traveled, came where the man was; and when he saw him, he took pity on him.
raw.note: The introduction of the unexpected hero in the Parable of the Good Samaritan.

raw.text: “Nazareth! Can anything good come from there?” Nathanael asked. “Come and see,” said Philip.
raw.note: Nathanael's skeptical response to hearing of Jesus's hometown, and Philip's simple invitation.

raw.text: When the day of Pentecost came, they were all together in one place.
raw.note: The setting for the outpouring of the Holy Spirit upon the early church.

raw.text: The wrath of God is being revealed from heaven against all the godlessness and wickedness of men who suppress the truth by their wickedness,
raw.note: Paul's introduction to his argument on human sinfulness, that God's wrath is revealed against the active suppression of truth.

raw.text: What I mean is this: One of you says, “I follow Paul”; another, “I follow Apollos”; another, “I follow Cephas”; still another, “I follow Christ.”
raw.note: Paul's description of the divisions and factions within the Corinthian church.

raw.text: And no wonder, for Satan himself masquerades as an angel of light.
raw.note: A warning about the deceptive nature of Satan, who can appear as something good.

raw.text: When Peter came to Antioch, I opposed him to his face, because he was clearly in the wrong.
raw.note: Paul's account of his public confrontation with Peter over the issue of hypocrisy.

raw.text: I pray that the eyes of your heart may be enlightened in order that you may know the hope to which He has called you, the riches of His glorious inheritance in the saints,
raw.note: From Paul's prayer for the Ephesians, a request for spiritual illumination to understand their hope and inheritance.

raw.text: And the peace of God, which transcends all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.
raw.note: A promise of a supernatural peace that surpasses human comprehension to guard the believer.

raw.text: He is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn over all creation.
raw.note: A high Christological statement, describing Christ as the perfect representation of the invisible God.

raw.text: Brothers, we do not want you to be ignorant about those who fall asleep, or to grieve like the rest of men, who have no hope.
raw.note: Paul's reason for teaching on the resurrection: to provide hope and comfort concerning deceased believers.

raw.text: We hear that some among you are idle. They are not busy; they are busybodies.
raw.note: A play on words used to describe those who were idly meddling in the affairs of others.

raw.text: He must not be a recent convert, or he may become conceited and fall under the same judgment as the devil.
raw.note: A qualification for an overseer, warning against appointing a new convert who is vulnerable to pride.

raw.text: Nevertheless, God’s solid foundation stands firm, sealed with this inscription: “The Lord knows those who are His,” and, “Everyone who confesses the name of the Lord must turn away from wickedness.”
raw.note: A metaphor of a sealed foundation to describe the security of the church, marked by divine knowledge and human responsibility.

raw.text: Warn a divisive person once, and then warn him a second time. After that, have nothing to do with him.
raw.note: An instruction on church discipline for a person who habitually causes division.

raw.text: Therefore, since the promise of entering His rest still stands, let us be careful that none of you be found to have fallen short of it.
raw.note: A warning to believers to be diligent to enter God's spiritual rest, drawing a lesson from Israel's failure.

raw.text: My brothers, as believers in our glorious Lord Jesus Christ, do not show favoritism.
raw.note: A direct command against showing partiality or favoritism within the church.

raw.text: For you know that it was not with perishable things such as silver or gold that you were redeemed from the empty way of life you inherited from your forefathers,
raw.note: A reminder of the precious cost of redemption, contrasting it with worthless, perishable things.

raw.text: He writes this way in all his letters, speaking in them of these matters. Some of his comments are hard to understand, which ignorant and unstable people distort, as they do the other Scriptures, to their own destruction.
raw.note: Peter's acknowledgement of the difficulty of some of Paul's writings and a warning against their distortion.

raw.text: If anyone has material possessions and sees his brother in need but has no pity on him, how can the love of God be in him?
raw.note: A rhetorical question testing the genuineness of one's love for God by their compassion for a brother in need.

raw.text: I looked, and there before me was a pale horse! Its rider was named Death, and Hades was following close behind him. They were given power over a fourth of the earth to kill by sword, famine, and plague, and by the wild beasts of the earth.
raw.note: The description of the fourth horseman of the Apocalypse, representing Death and Hades.

raw.text: And he cried out in a mighty voice: “Fallen, fallen is Babylon the great! She has become a dwelling for demons and a haunt for every unclean spirit, a haunt for every unclean and detestable bird.
raw.note: The angelic proclamation of the fall of Babylon, describing its utter desolation and demonic habitation.

raw.text: That is why it was called Babel, because there the LORD confused the language of the whole world. From there the LORD scattered them over the face of the whole earth.
raw.note: The etiological explanation for the name Babel and the origin of different languages.

raw.text: “Who among the gods is like You, O LORD? Who is like You—majestic in holiness, awesome in glory, working wonders?
raw.note: From the Song of Moses, a rhetorical question celebrating the unique and incomparable nature of God.

raw.text: The steps of a good man are ordered by the LORD, and He delights in his way.
raw.note: A statement of divine providence, that God directs the path of the righteous.

raw.text: The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, and he who wins souls is wise.
raw.note: A proverb linking righteousness to life-giving influence and soul-winning to wisdom.

raw.text: I have swept away your transgressions like a cloud, your sins like the morning mist. Return to Me, for I have redeemed you.”
raw.note: A powerful metaphor for the complete and total removal of sin by God's redemption.

raw.text: “Behold, the days are coming,” declares the LORD, “when I will raise up for David a righteous Branch, and He will reign as King and act wisely and administer justice and righteousness in the land.
raw.note: A key messianic prophecy of a future Davidic king, referred to as 'the Branch'.

raw.text: “The kingdom of heaven is like treasure hidden in a field. When a man found it, he hid it again, and in his joy he went and sold all he had and bought that field.
raw.note: A parable illustrating the supreme value of the kingdom of heaven, worth sacrificing everything for.

raw.text: Jesus called out with a loud voice, “Father, into Your hands I commit My spirit.” And when He had said this, He breathed His last.
raw.note: Jesus's final words from the cross, entrusting His spirit to the Father.

raw.text: Jesus replied, “Truly, truly, I tell you, no one can see the kingdom of God unless he is born again.”
raw.note: Jesus's teaching to Nicodemus on the necessity of the new birth for entering God's kingdom.

raw.text: And He is not served by human hands, as if He needed anything, because He Himself gives all men life and breath and everything else.
raw.note: From Paul's sermon in Athens, a statement on God's self-sufficiency.

raw.text: No, in all these things we are more than conquerors through Him who loved us.
raw.note: A declaration of overwhelming victory for believers amidst trials, through the love of Christ.

raw.text: “Where, O death, is your victory? Where, O death, is your sting?”
raw.note: A taunt against death, quoted from Hosea, celebrating its defeat through Christ's resurrection.

raw.text: If you belong to Christ, then you are Abraham’s seed, and heirs according to the promise.
raw.note: A statement on spiritual lineage, that all who are in Christ are the true descendants of Abraham and heirs of the promise.

raw.text: As for you, you were dead in your transgressions and sins,
raw.note: A description of the spiritual condition of humanity apart from Christ.

raw.text: And being found in appearance as a man, He humbled Himself and became obedient to death—even death on a cross!
raw.note: The culmination of Christ's humiliation, His obedience leading to the ultimate degradation of crucifixion.

raw.text: But now He has reconciled you by Christ’s physical body through death to present you holy, unblemished, and blameless in His presence—
raw.note: The purpose of Christ's reconciliation: to present believers as holy and blameless before God.

raw.text: who gave Himself as a ransom for all—the testimony given in its proper time.
raw.note: A concise statement of Christ's substitutionary death as a ransom for all people.

raw.text: so also Christ was offered once to bear the sins of many; and He will appear a second time, not to bear sin, but to bring salvation to those who are eagerly waiting for Him.
raw.note: A contrast between Christ's first coming (to bear sin) and His second coming (to bring final salvation).

raw.text: In the same way, faith by itself, if it is not accompanied by action, is dead.
raw.note: A clear statement that genuine faith is inherently active and produces works.

raw.text: Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ! By His great mercy He has given us new birth into a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead,
raw.note: A doxology praising God for the new birth, which results in a living, active hope.

raw.text: All inhabitants of the earth will worship the beast—all whose names have not been written in the book of life belonging to the Lamb that was slain from the foundation of the world.
raw.note: A statement on the eternal nature of Christ's sacrifice, planned from before the world's foundation.

raw.text: I did not see a temple in the city, because the Lord God Almighty and the Lamb are its temple.
raw.note: A description of the New Jerusalem, where the unmediated presence of God and the Lamb replaces the need for a physical temple.

raw.text: Then Jacob gave Esau some bread and some lentil stew. He ate and drank, and then got up and left. So Esau despised his birthright.
raw.note: The account of Esau selling his birthright for a meal, showing his disregard for his inheritance.

raw.text: “It is the finger of God,” the magicians said to Pharaoh. But Pharaoh’s heart was hard, and he would not listen, just as the LORD had said.
raw.note: The Egyptian magicians' confession of God's power after failing to replicate the plague of gnats.

raw.text: You are to season each of your grain offerings with salt. You must not leave the salt of the covenant of your God out of your grain offerings. You are to offer salt with all your offerings.
raw.note: A legal requirement for all grain offerings to include salt, symbolizing the enduring nature of the covenant.

raw.text: But because My servant Caleb has a different spirit and follows Me wholeheartedly, I will bring him into the land he has entered, and his descendants will inherit it.
raw.note: God's commendation of Caleb for his wholehearted faithfulness, contrasting him with the rebellious generation.

raw.text: Acknowledge and take to heart this day that the LORD is God in heaven above and on the earth below. There is no other.
raw.note: A call to internalize the truth of God's exclusive and universal sovereignty.

raw.text: Over Achan they heaped up a large pile of rocks, which remains to this day. Then the LORD turned from His fierce anger. Therefore that place has been called the Valley of Achor to this day.
raw.note: The consequence of Achan's sin, resulting in his execution and the naming of the valley.

raw.text: for you will conceive and give birth to a son. No razor may be used on his head, because the boy is to be a Nazirite, dedicated to God from the womb. He will begin the deliverance of Israel from the hands of the Philistines.”
raw.note: The angelic announcement of Samson's birth, setting him apart as a Nazirite from conception.

raw.text: The LORD sends poverty and wealth; He humbles and He exalts.
raw.note: From Hannah's prayer, a declaration of the LORD's sovereign control over human fortune and status.

raw.text: I will become even more undignified than this, and I will be humiliated in my own eyes. But by these slave girls you have mentioned, I will be held in honor.”
raw.note: David's response to Michal's criticism, declaring his willingness to be humiliated for the sake of worshiping God.

raw.text: At noon Elijah began to taunt them. “Shout louder!” he said. “Surely he is a god! Perhaps he is deep in thought, or busy, or traveling. Maybe he is sleeping and must be awakened.”
raw.note: Elijah's sarcastic mockery of the prophets of Baal during the contest on Mount Carmel.

raw.text: Then Elijah took his cloak, rolled it up, and struck the water. The water divided to the right and to the left, and the two of them crossed over on dry ground.
raw.note: Elijah's miracle of parting the Jordan River before his ascension.

raw.text: Look to the LORD and His strength; seek His face always.
raw.note: An exhortation to continually seek God's presence and power.

raw.text: For I have now chosen and consecrated this temple so that My Name may be there forever. My eyes and My heart will always be there.
raw.note: God's response after Solomon's prayer, declaring His choice and sanctification of the temple as His dwelling place.

raw.text: While Ezra was praying and confessing, weeping and throwing himself down before the house of God, a very large crowd of Israelites—men, women, and children—gathered around him. They too wept bitterly.
raw.note: The scene of corporate repentance spurred by Ezra's personal grief and confession.

raw.text: The whole assembly that had returned from the exile made booths and lived in them. From the days of Joshua son of Nun until that day, the Israelites had not celebrated it with such great joy.
raw.note: The joyful revival of the Feast of Tabernacles after the reading of the Law.

raw.text: In every province and in every city to which the edict of the king came, there was joy and gladness among the Jews, with feasting and celebrating. And many people of other nationalities became Jews because fear of the Jews had seized them.
raw.note: The widespread celebration and influence of the Jews after their deliverance was decreed.

raw.text: Then the LORD said to Satan, “Have you considered My servant Job? There is no one on earth like him, a man of perfect integrity, who fears God and shuns evil.”
raw.note: God's own testimony concerning Job's exceptional character before the trials begin.

raw.text: Surely goodness and mercy will follow me all the days of my life, and I will dwell in the house of the LORD forever.
raw.note: The concluding verse of the Shepherd's Psalm, a confident declaration of God's lifelong pursuit and the hope of eternal fellowship.

raw.text: How can a young man keep his way pure? By living according to Your word.
raw.note: A question and answer on the means of maintaining personal purity: obedience to Scripture.

raw.text: A false balance is an abomination to the LORD, but an accurate weight is His delight.
raw.note: A proverb contrasting dishonest and honest business practices from God's perspective.

raw.text: He who conceals his sins does not prosper, but whoever confesses and renounces them finds mercy.
raw.note: A wisdom saying on the outcome of concealing versus confessing sin.

raw.text: Yet when I surveyed all that my hands had done and what I had toiled to achieve, everything was meaningless, a chasing after the wind; there was nothing to be gained under the sun.
raw.note: The Preacher's conclusion after pursuing pleasure and accomplishment: it is all ultimately meaningless.

raw.text: “Woe to me!” I cried. “I am ruined! For I am a man of unclean lips, and I live among a people of unclean lips, and my eyes have seen the King, the LORD of Hosts.”
raw.note: Isaiah's reaction of despair and conviction of his own sinfulness upon seeing the holiness of God.

raw.text: “Ah, Lord GOD,” I said, “I do not know how to speak, for I am only a child.”
raw.note: Jeremiah's initial objection to his prophetic call, based on his youth and inexperience.

raw.text: “So I sought for a man among them who would build up the wall and stand in the gap before Me for the land, so that I would not have to destroy it. But I found no one.
raw.note: God's lament over the lack of a righteous intercessor to stand on behalf of the sinful land.

raw.text: The king said to Daniel, “Surely your God is the God of gods and the Lord of kings and a revealer of mysteries, for you were able to reveal this mystery.”
raw.note: King Nebuchadnezzar's confession of God's greatness after Daniel interprets his dream.

raw.text: How can I give you up, Ephraim? How can I hand you over, Israel? How can I treat you like Admah? How can I make you like Zeboiim? My heart is changed within Me; all My compassion is aroused.
raw.note: A powerful expression of God's anguished love and compassion for His rebellious people.

raw.text: Blessed are the meek, for they will inherit the earth.
raw.note: One of the Beatitudes, promising the inheritance of the earth to the gentle and humble.

raw.text: Truly I tell you, anyone who will not receive the kingdom of God like a little child will never enter it.”
raw.note: Jesus's teaching on the necessity of childlike humility and dependence to enter God's kingdom.

raw.text: Now there was a man in Jerusalem called Simeon, who was righteous and devout. He was waiting for the consolation of Israel, and the Holy Spirit was upon him.
raw.note: The introduction of Simeon, a righteous man expectantly waiting for the coming of the Messiah.

raw.text: Yet to all who received Him, to those who believed in His name, He gave the right to become children of God—
raw.note: A statement on the basis of becoming a child of God: receiving and believing in Christ.

raw.text: As for us, we cannot help speaking about what we have seen and heard.”
raw.note: Peter and John's response to the Sanhedrin, expressing the irresistible compulsion to share their testimony.

raw.text: Paul, a servant of Christ Jesus, called to be an apostle, and set apart for the gospel of God,
raw.note: Paul's self-introduction in his letter to the Romans, defining his identity and calling.

raw.text: I appeal to you, brothers, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you agree with one another so that there may be no divisions among you and that you may be perfectly united in mind and thought.
raw.note: Paul's appeal to the Corinthian church to resolve their internal divisions and pursue unity.

raw.text: All this is from God, who reconciled us to Himself through Christ and gave us the ministry of reconciliation:
raw.note: A statement on the origin and nature of the Christian ministry: a ministry of reconciliation from God.

raw.text: The acts of the flesh are obvious: sexual immorality, impurity, and debauchery;
raw.note: The beginning of the list of the works of the flesh, contrasting with the fruit of the Spirit.

raw.text: And in Him you too are being built together to become a dwelling in which God lives by His Spirit.
raw.note: A metaphor for the church as a spiritual building, a dwelling place for God.

raw.text: then make my joy complete by being like-minded, having the same love, being one in spirit and purpose.
raw.note: Paul's plea for unity among the Philippians, defining it as having the same mind and love.

raw.text: Therefore, as God’s chosen people, holy and dearly loved, clothe yourselves with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness, and patience.
raw.note: An exhortation for believers to 'put on' various Christian virtues, as befits their new identity.

raw.text: We continually remember before our God and Father your work produced by faith, your labor prompted by love, and your endurance inspired by hope in our Lord Jesus Christ.
raw.note: Paul's commendation of the Thessalonians, highlighting the triad of faith, love, and hope as the source of their Christian life.

raw.text: We ought always to thank God for you, brothers, and rightly so, because your faith is growing more and more, and the love every one of you has for each other is increasing.
raw.note: Paul's thanksgiving for the spiritual growth of the Thessalonian believers.

raw.text: Command them to do good, to be rich in good deeds, and to be generous and willing to share.
raw.note: A pastoral instruction for the wealthy, directing them to use their resources for good works and generosity.

raw.text: Flee the evil desires of youth and pursue righteousness, faith, love, and peace, along with those who call on the Lord out of a pure heart.
raw.note: A command to Timothy to both avoid youthful passions and actively pursue Christian virtues in community.

raw.text: For the grace of God has appeared, bringing salvation to all men.
raw.note: A statement on the universal offer of salvation brought by the grace of God.

raw.text: Through Jesus, therefore, let us continually offer to God a sacrifice of praise—the fruit of lips that confess His name.
raw.note: Defining the Christian's spiritual sacrifice as continual praise and confession of God's name.

raw.text: Therefore, get rid of all moral filth and the evil that is so prevalent, and humbly accept the word planted in you, which can save you.
raw.note: An exhortation to both put off sin and humbly receive the word of God.

raw.text: you also, like living stones, are being built into a spiritual house to be a holy priesthood, offering spiritual sacrifices acceptable to God through Jesus Christ.
raw.note: A metaphor describing believers as living stones being built into a spiritual temple.

raw.text: Through these He has given us His precious and magnificent promises, so that through them you may become partakers of the divine nature, now that you have escaped the corruption in the world caused by evil desires.
raw.note: Describes the purpose of God's promises: to enable believers to share in the divine nature.

raw.text: for everyone born of God overcomes the world. This is the victory that has overcome the world, even our faith.
raw.note: A declaration that every believer is a world-overcomer, and that this victory is achieved through faith.

raw.text: I, John, your brother and companion in the suffering and kingdom and patient endurance that are ours in Jesus, was on the island of Patmos because of the word of God and the testimony of Jesus.
raw.note: John's self-introduction, identifying his location and the reason for his exile.

raw.text: Let him who does wrong continue to do wrong; let him who is vile continue to be vile; let him who does right continue to do right; and let him who is holy continue to be holy.”
raw.note: A solemn declaration of the fixed states of humanity just before the final judgment.

raw.text: Behold, I am with you and will watch over you wherever you go, and I will bring you back to this land. For I will not leave you until I have done what I have promised you.”
raw.note: God's promise to Jacob at Bethel, assuring him of His constant presence and faithfulness.

raw.text: The LORD would speak to Moses face to face, as a man speaks with his friend. Then Moses would return to the camp, but his young assistant Joshua son of Nun did not leave the tent.
raw.note: A description of the unique intimacy of Moses's relationship with God.

raw.text: Show me Your ways, O LORD, teach me Your paths.
raw.note: A simple prayer for divine guidance and instruction.

raw.text: Pride goes before destruction, and a haughty spirit before a fall.
raw.note: A proverb on the inevitable downfall that follows pride.

raw.text: When you pass through the waters, I will be with you; and when you pass through the rivers, they will not sweep over you. When you walk through the fire, you will not be burned; the flames will not set you ablaze.
raw.note: A promise of God's protective presence through all of life's trials, symbolized by water and fire.

raw.text: But blessed is the man who trusts in the LORD, whose confidence is in Him.
raw.note: A beatitude for the one whose trust and confidence are placed in the LORD.

raw.text: “Do not judge, or you too will be judged.
raw.note: A command against having a judgmental and hypocritical attitude.

raw.text: Be merciful, just as your Father is merciful.
raw.note: A command for believers to imitate the merciful character of God the Father.

raw.text: I no longer call you servants, because a servant does not know his master’s business. Instead, I have called you friends, for everything that I learned from My Father I have made known to you.
raw.note: Jesus elevating the status of His disciples from servants to friends, based on intimate knowledge.

raw.text: And they prayed, “Lord, You know everyone’s heart. Show us which of these two You have chosen
raw.note: The apostles' prayer before choosing a replacement for Judas, acknowledging God's knowledge of the heart.

raw.text: Be joyful in hope, patient in affliction, faithful in prayer.
raw.note: A triad of commands for Christian conduct in relation to the future, present, and God.

raw.text: For the message of the cross is foolishness to those who are perishing, but to us who are being saved it is the power of God.
raw.note: A contrast between the world's perception of the cross and its reality for believers.

raw.text: From now on, let no one cause me trouble, for I bear on my body the marks of Jesus.
raw.note: Paul's reference to his physical scars from persecution as the marks of his ownership by Jesus.

raw.text: Get rid of all bitterness, rage and anger, brawling and slander, along with every form of malice.
raw.note: A command to put off various sinful attitudes and actions that destroy community.

raw.text: Whatever you have learned or received or heard from me, or seen in me—put it into practice. And the God of peace will be with you.
raw.note: Paul's call for the Philippians to imitate his example, with the promise of God's peace.

raw.text: Have nothing to do with godless myths and old wives’ tales; rather, train yourself to be godly.
raw.note: An instruction to avoid worthless controversies and instead actively pursue godliness.

raw.text: God did this so that, by two unchangeable things in which it is impossible for God to lie, we who have fled to take hold of the hope offered to us may be greatly encouraged.
raw.note: An explanation of the certainty of God's promise, based on His oath and His truthful nature.

raw.text: When tempted, no one should say, “God is tempting me.” For God cannot be tempted by evil, nor does He tempt anyone;
raw.note: A clarification on the source of temptation, absolving God of any role in tempting individuals to evil.

raw.text: But even if you should suffer for what is right, you are blessed. “Do not fear what they fear; do not be frightened.”
raw.note: An encouragement to believers facing persecution, redefining suffering for righteousness as a blessing.

raw.text: He who has an ear, let him hear what the Spirit says to the churches. To him who overcomes, I will give some of the hidden manna. I will also give him a white stone with a new name written on it, known only to him who receives it.
raw.note: The promise to the overcomer in the church of Pergamum, involving secret spiritual nourishment and a new identity.

raw.text: He who testifies to these things says, “Yes, I am coming soon.” Amen. Come, Lord Jesus!
raw.note: The final prayer of the Bible, an eager plea for the return of Christ.

raw.text: Then Joseph remembered his dreams about them and said to them, “You are spies! You have come to see where our land is unprotected.”
raw.note: Joseph accusing his brothers, setting in motion the test of their character.

raw.text: eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,
raw.note: A foundational principle of retributive justice in the Mosaic Law, known as 'lex talionis'.

raw.text: The goat will carry on itself all their iniquities to a solitary place, and the man shall release it in the wilderness.
raw.note: The description of the scapegoat on the Day of Atonement, symbolically carrying away the sins of the people.

raw.text: But Balaam said to Balak, “See, I have come to you. But can I say just anything? I must speak only the word that God puts in my mouth.”
raw.note: Balaam's statement to King Balak, acknowledging his constraint to speak only God's message.

raw.text: It is to be with him, and he is to read it all the days of his life, so that he may learn to revere the LORD his God and follow carefully all the words of this law and these decrees
raw.note: The requirement for the king of Israel to constantly read and study the Law of God.

raw.text: Then Joshua son of Nun secretly sent two spies from Shittim. “Go, look over the land,” he said, “especially Jericho.” So they went and entered the house of a prostitute named Rahab and stayed there.
raw.note: The beginning of the Jericho reconnaissance mission, introducing the key character Rahab.

raw.text: “I will certainly go with you,” said Deborah. “But because of the way you are going about this, the honor will not be yours, for the LORD will deliver Sisera into the hands of a woman.”
raw.note: Deborah's prophecy to Barak, foretelling that the glory of victory would go to a woman.

raw.text: Samuel said to Saul, “Why have you disturbed me by bringing me up?” “I am in great distress,” Saul said. “The Philistines are fighting against me, and God has turned away from me. He no longer answers me, either by prophets or by dreams. So I have called on you to tell me what to do.”
raw.note: The confrontation between the spirit of Samuel and King Saul at Endor.

raw.text: Then Nathan said to David, “You are the man! This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: ‘I anointed you king over Israel, and I delivered you from the hand of Saul.
raw.note: The prophet Nathan's direct and courageous confrontation of King David after his sin with Bathsheba.

raw.text: When King Jeroboam heard the word that the man of God cried out against the altar at Bethel, he stretched out his hand from the altar and said, “Seize him!” But the hand he stretched out toward the man shriveled up, so that he could not pull it back.
raw.note: A miraculous judgment on King Jeroboam for trying to harm the man of God.

raw.text: In those days Hezekiah became ill and was at the point of death. The prophet Isaiah son of Amoz went to him and said, “This is what the LORD says: Put your house in order, because you are going to die; you will not recover.”
raw.note: The initial grim prognosis given to King Hezekiah by the prophet Isaiah.

raw.text: Then Satan rose up against Israel and incited David to take a census of Israel.
raw.note: The account of David's sinful census, attributed here to the incitement of Satan.

raw.text: But when envoys were sent by the rulers of Babylon to ask him about the miraculous sign that had occurred in the land, God left him to test him and to know everything that was in his heart.
raw.note: An explanation for Hezekiah's failure, that God tested him to reveal the pride in his heart.

raw.text: And you, Ezra, in accordance with the wisdom of your God, which you possess, are to appoint magistrates and judges to administer justice for all the people of Trans-Euphrates—all who know the laws of your God. And you are to teach any who do not know them.
raw.note: The commission given to Ezra by King Artaxerxes to establish a judicial and educational system based on God's law.

raw.text: When I heard these things, I sat down and wept. For some days I mourned and fasted and prayed before the God of heaven.
raw.note: Nehemiah's immediate and heartfelt response of grief and prayer upon hearing of Jerusalem's condition.

raw.text: When Mordecai learned of all that had been done, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth and ashes, and went out into the city, wailing loudly and bitterly.
raw.note: The traditional signs of deep mourning and distress displayed by Mordecai.

raw.text: So Satan went out from the presence of the LORD and afflicted Job with painful sores from the soles of his feet to the crown of his head.
raw.note: The second test of Job, involving severe physical affliction.

raw.text: In peace I will lie down and sleep, for You alone, O LORD, make me dwell in safety.
raw.note: A declaration of peaceful rest based on the security found only in the LORD.

raw.text: He split the rocks in the wilderness and gave them water as abundant as the seas;
raw.note: A poetic recounting of God's miraculous provision of water from a rock in the desert.

raw.text: “The LORD possessed me at the beginning of His work, before His deeds of old.
raw.note: From the poem on wisdom, a personification of wisdom describing her existence with God before creation.

raw.text: If your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat; if he is thirsty, give him water to drink.
raw.note: A wisdom saying commanding proactive kindness toward one's enemies.

raw.text: A good name is better than fine perfume, and the day of death better than the day of birth.
raw.note: A paradoxical proverb from the Teacher, valuing reputation over luxury and the end of life over its beginning.

raw.text: Learn to do right; seek justice. Defend the oppressed. Take up the cause of the fatherless; plead the case of the widow.
raw.note: A call to practical righteousness, defined by active pursuit of social justice for the vulnerable.

raw.text: This is what the LORD says: “A voice is heard in Ramah, mourning and great weeping, Rachel weeping for her children and refusing to be comforted, because they are no more.”
raw.note: A prophecy of the grief of the exile, later applied by Matthew to the slaughter of the infants in Bethlehem.

raw.text: And I went to the exiles at Tel-abib who lived by the Kebar River. And there, where they were living, I sat among them for seven days, overwhelmed.
raw.note: Ezekiel's initial reaction to his prophetic call and the condition of the exiles, sitting in stunned silence.

raw.text: Suddenly the fingers of a human hand appeared and wrote on the plaster of the wall, near the lampstand in the royal palace. The king watched the hand as it wrote.
raw.note: The terrifying appearance of the disembodied hand that wrote the message of judgment on the wall.

raw.text: When they had gone, an angel of the Lord appeared to Joseph in a dream. “Get up,” he said, “take the child and his mother and escape to Egypt. Stay there until I tell you, for Herod is going to search for the child to kill him.”
raw.note: The angelic warning to Joseph, prompting the flight to Egypt to escape Herod's persecution.

raw.text: Then Jesus asked him, “What is your name?” “My name is Legion,” he replied, “for we are many.”
raw.note: The self-identification of the demons possessing the man from the Gerasenes, indicating a massive infestation.

raw.text: But a Samaritan, as he traveled, came where the man was; and when he saw him, he took pity on him.
raw.note: The introduction of the unexpected hero in the Parable of the Good Samaritan.

raw.text: “Nazareth! Can anything good come from there?” Nathanael asked. “Come and see,” said Philip.
raw.note: Nathanael's skeptical response to hearing of Jesus's hometown, and Philip's simple invitation.

raw.text: When the day of Pentecost came, they were all together in one place.
raw.note: The setting for the outpouring of the Holy Spirit upon the early church.

raw.text: The wrath of God is being revealed from heaven against all the godlessness and wickedness of men who suppress the truth by their wickedness,
raw.note: Paul's introduction to his argument on human sinfulness, that God's wrath is revealed against the active suppression of truth.

raw.text: What I mean is this: One of you says, “I follow Paul”; another, “I follow Apollos”; another, “I follow Cephas”; still another, “I follow Christ.”
raw.note: Paul's description of the divisions and factions within the Corinthian church.

raw.text: And no wonder, for Satan himself masquerades as an angel of light.
raw.note: A warning about the deceptive nature of Satan, who can appear as something good.

raw.text: When Peter came to Antioch, I opposed him to his face, because he was clearly in the wrong.
raw.note: Paul's account of his public confrontation with Peter over the issue of hypocrisy.

raw.text: I pray that the eyes of your heart may be enlightened in order that you may know the hope to which He has called you, the riches of His glorious inheritance in the saints,
raw.note: From Paul's prayer for the Ephesians, a request for spiritual illumination to understand their hope and inheritance.

raw.text: And the peace of God, which transcends all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.
raw.note: A promise of a supernatural peace that surpasses human comprehension to guard the believer.

raw.text: He is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn over all creation.
raw.note: A high Christological statement, describing Christ as the perfect representation of the invisible God.

raw.text: Brothers, we do not want you to be ignorant about those who fall asleep, or to grieve like the rest of men, who have no hope.
raw.note: Paul's reason for teaching on the resurrection: to provide hope and comfort concerning deceased believers.

raw.text: We hear that some among you are idle. They are not busy; they are busybodies.
raw.note: A play on words used to describe those who were idly meddling in the affairs of others.

raw.text: He must not be a recent convert, or he may become conceited and fall under the same judgment as the devil.
raw.note: A qualification for an overseer, warning against appointing a new convert who is vulnerable to pride.

raw.text: Nevertheless, God’s solid foundation stands firm, sealed with this inscription: “The Lord knows those who are His,” and, “Everyone who confesses the name of the Lord must turn away from wickedness.”
raw.note: A metaphor of a sealed foundation to describe the security of the church, marked by divine knowledge and human responsibility.

raw.text: Warn a divisive person once, and then warn him a second time. After that, have nothing to do with him.
raw.note: An instruction on church discipline for a person who habitually causes division.

raw.text: Therefore, since the promise of entering His rest still stands, let us be careful that none of you be found to have fallen short of it.
raw.note: A warning to believers to be diligent to enter God's spiritual rest, drawing a lesson from Israel's failure.

raw.text: My brothers, as believers in our glorious Lord Jesus Christ, do not show favoritism.
raw.note: A direct command against showing partiality or favoritism within the church.

raw.text: For you know that it was not with perishable things such as silver or gold that you were redeemed from the empty way of life you inherited from your forefathers,
raw.note: A reminder of the precious cost of redemption, contrasting it with worthless, perishable things.

raw.text: He writes this way in all his letters, speaking in them of these matters. Some of his comments are hard to understand, which ignorant and unstable people distort, as they do the other Scriptures, to their own destruction.
raw.note: Peter's acknowledgement of the difficulty of some of Paul's writings and a warning against their distortion.

raw.text: If anyone has material possessions and sees his brother in need but has no pity on him, how can the love of God be in him?
raw.note: A rhetorical question testing the genuineness of one's love for God by their compassion for a brother in need.

raw.text: I looked, and there before me was a pale horse! Its rider was named Death, and Hades was following close behind him. They were given power over a fourth of the earth to kill by sword, famine, and plague, and by the wild beasts of the earth.
raw.note: The description of the fourth horseman of the Apocalypse, representing Death and Hades.

raw.text: And he cried out in a mighty voice: “Fallen, fallen is Babylon the great! She has become a dwelling for demons and a haunt for every unclean spirit, a haunt for every unclean and detestable bird.
raw.note: The angelic proclamation of the fall of Babylon, describing its utter desolation and demonic habitation.

raw.text: That is why it was called Babel, because there the LORD confused the language of the whole world. From there the LORD scattered them over the face of the whole earth.
raw.note: The etiological explanation for the name Babel and the origin of different languages.

raw.text: “Who among the gods is like You, O LORD? Who is like You—majestic in holiness, awesome in glory, working wonders?
raw.note: From the Song of Moses, a rhetorical question celebrating the unique and incomparable nature of God.

raw.text: The steps of a good man are ordered by the LORD, and He delights in his way.
raw.note: A statement of divine providence, that God directs the path of the righteous.

raw.text: The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, and he who wins souls is wise.
raw.note: A proverb linking righteousness to life-giving influence and soul-winning to wisdom.

raw.text: I have swept away your transgressions like a cloud, your sins like the morning mist. Return to Me, for I have redeemed you.”
raw.note: A powerful metaphor for the complete and total removal of sin by God's redemption.

raw.text: “Behold, the days are coming,” declares the LORD, “when I will raise up for David a righteous Branch, and He will reign as King and act wisely and administer justice and righteousness in the land.
raw.note: A key messianic prophecy of a future Davidic king, referred to as 'the Branch'.

raw.text: “The kingdom of heaven is like treasure hidden in a field. When a man found it, he hid it again, and in his joy he went and sold all he had and bought that field.
raw.note: A parable illustrating the supreme value of the kingdom of heaven, worth sacrificing everything for.

raw.text: Jesus called out with a loud voice, “Father, into Your hands I commit My spirit.” And when He had said this, He breathed His last.
raw.note: Jesus's final words from the cross, entrusting His spirit to the Father.

raw.text: Jesus replied, “Truly, truly, I tell you, no one can see the kingdom of God unless he is born again.”
raw.note: Jesus's teaching to Nicodemus on the necessity of the new birth for entering God's kingdom.

raw.text: And He is not served by human hands, as if He needed anything, because He Himself gives all men life and breath and everything else.
raw.note: From Paul's sermon in Athens, a statement on God's self-sufficiency.

raw.text: No, in all these things we are more than conquerors through Him who loved us.
raw.note: A declaration of overwhelming victory for believers amidst trials, through the love of Christ.

raw.text: “Where, O death, is your victory? Where, O death, is your sting?”
raw.note: A taunt against death, quoted from Hosea, celebrating its defeat through Christ's resurrection.

raw.text: If you belong to Christ, then you are Abraham’s seed, and heirs according to the promise.
raw.note: A statement on spiritual lineage, that all who are in Christ are the true descendants of Abraham and heirs of the promise.

raw.text: As for you, you were dead in your transgressions and sins,
raw.note: A description of the spiritual condition of humanity apart from Christ.

raw.text: And being found in appearance as a man, He humbled Himself and became obedient to death—even death on a cross!
raw.note: The culmination of Christ's humiliation, His obedience leading to the ultimate degradation of crucifixion.

raw.text: But now He has reconciled you by Christ’s physical body through death to present you holy, unblemished, and blameless in His presence—
raw.note: The purpose of Christ's reconciliation: to present believers as holy and blameless before God.

raw.text: who gave Himself as a ransom for all—the testimony given in its proper time.
raw.note: A concise statement of Christ's substitutionary death as a ransom for all people.

raw.text: so also Christ was offered once to bear the sins of many; and He will appear a second time, not to bear sin, but to bring salvation to those who are eagerly waiting for Him.
raw.note: A contrast between Christ's first coming (to bear sin) and His second coming (to bring final salvation).

raw.text: In the same way, faith by itself, if it is not accompanied by action, is dead.
raw.note: A clear statement that genuine faith is inherently active and produces works.

raw.text: Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ! By His great mercy He has given us new birth into a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead,
raw.note: A doxology praising God for the new birth, which results in a living, active hope.

raw.text: All inhabitants of the earth will worship the beast—all whose names have not been written in the book of life belonging to the Lamb that was slain from the foundation of the world.
raw.note: A statement on the eternal nature of Christ's sacrifice, planned from before the world's foundation.

raw.text: I did not see a temple in the city, because the Lord God Almighty and the Lamb are its temple.
raw.note: A description of the New Jerusalem, where the unmediated presence of God and the Lamb replaces the need for a physical temple.

raw.text: then the LORD your God will restore your fortunes and have compassion on you and gather you again from all the nations where He has scattered you.
raw.note: A promise of restoration from exile contingent on repentance.

raw.text: In those days Israel had no king; everyone did what was right in his own eyes.
raw.note: The closing statement of Judges, summarizing the era's anarchy.

raw.text: Your house and your kingdom will endure forever before Me; your throne will be established forever.’”
raw.note: The Davidic Covenant, promising an eternal kingdom and throne.

raw.text: After the earthquake there was a fire, but the LORD was not in the fire. And after the fire came a gentle whisper.
raw.note: God reveals His presence to Elijah not in grand displays, but in a quiet whisper.

raw.note: A prophetic word of encouragement before a battle, emphasizing divine sovereignty.

raw.text: “Go and enjoy choice food and sweet drinks,” he said. “And send some to those who have nothing prepared. For this day is holy to our Lord. Do not grieve, for the joy of the LORD is your strength.”
raw.note: Instruction to celebrate a holy day with joy and generosity.

raw.text: and said: “Naked I came from my mother’s womb, and naked I will return. The LORD gave and the LORD has taken away. Blessed be the name of the LORD.”
raw.note: Job's response of worship amidst immense personal tragedy.

raw.text: So teach us to number our days, that we may present to You a heart of wisdom.
raw.note: A prayer for perspective on the brevity of life to cultivate wisdom.

raw.text: As iron sharpens iron, so one man sharpens another.
raw.note: A proverb on the value of mutual encouragement and challenge in friendship.

raw.text: When all has been heard, the conclusion of the matter is this: Fear God and keep His commandments, because this is the whole duty of man.
raw.note: The conclusion of Ecclesiastes, summarizing human purpose.

raw.text: “Come now, let us reason together,” says the LORD. “Though your sins are like scarlet, they will be as white as snow; though they are as red as crimson, they will be like wool.
raw.note: A powerful metaphor for the totality of God's forgiveness.

raw.text: “But this is the covenant I will make with the house of Israel after those days, declares the LORD. I will put My law in their minds and write it on their hearts. I will be their God, and they will be My people.
raw.note: The prophecy of the New Covenant, where God's law is internalized.

raw.text: I will give you a new heart and put a new spirit in you; I will remove from you your heart of stone and give you a heart of flesh.
raw.note: A promise of spiritual regeneration and transformation.

raw.text: In the days of those kings, the God of heaven will set up a kingdom that will never be destroyed, nor will it be left to another people. It will crush all those kingdoms and bring them to an end, but it will itself endure forever.
raw.note: Daniel's interpretation of the dream, prophesying God's eternal kingdom.

raw.text: “Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
raw.note: The first of the Beatitudes from the Sermon on the Mount.

raw.text: So then, this is how you should pray: ‘Our Father in heaven, hallowed be Your name,
raw.note: The beginning of the Lord's Prayer.

raw.text: There He was transfigured before them. His face shone like the sun, and His clothes became as white as the light.
raw.note: The description of the Transfiguration of Jesus.

raw.text: “Father, if You are willing, take this cup from Me. Yet not My will, but Yours be done.”
raw.note: Jesus's prayer of submission in the Garden of Gethsemane.

raw.text: When Jesus had received the sour wine, He said, “It is finished.” And bowing His head, He gave up His spirit.
raw.note: Jesus's final words from the cross, declaring the completion of his work.

raw.text: All of them were filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in other tongues as the Spirit enabled them.
raw.note: The events of the day of Pentecost, marking the birth of the church.

raw.text: I am not ashamed of the gospel, because it is the power of God for salvation to everyone who believes, first to the Jew, then to the Greek.
raw.note: Paul's thesis statement for the book of Romans on the power of the gospel.

raw.text: For the message of the cross is foolishness to those who are perishing, but to us who are being saved it is the power of God.
raw.note: Contrasts the world's perception of the cross with its reality for believers.

raw.text: Now we have this treasure in jars of clay to show that this surpassingly great power is from God and not from us.
raw.note: A metaphor for the gospel being held in fragile human messengers to display God's power.

raw.text: Carry each other’s burdens, and in this way you will fulfill the law of Christ.
raw.note: An instruction on mutual support as the fulfillment of Christ's law.

raw.text: For we are God’s workmanship, created in Christ Jesus to do good works, which God prepared in advance for us to do.
raw.note: Believers are described as God's creation, designed for good works.

raw.text: For to me, to live is Christ and to die is gain.
raw.note: Paul's summary of his life's purpose and perspective on death.

raw.text: And He is the head of the body, the church; He is the beginning and the firstborn from among the dead, so that in everything He might have the supremacy.
raw.note: Describes Christ's supremacy as the head of the church and firstborn from the dead.

raw.text: Rejoice always,
raw.note: A concise and direct command to maintain a state of joy.

raw.text: and to grant relief to you who are oppressed and to us as well. This will happen when the Lord Jesus is revealed from heaven in blazing fire with His powerful angels,
raw.note: A description of the second coming of Christ with power and judgment.

raw.text: This is a trustworthy saying: If anyone aspires to be an overseer, he desires a noble task.
raw.note: The introduction to the qualifications for church leadership.

raw.text: I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith.
raw.note: Paul's reflection on his life and ministry near its end.

raw.text: while we wait for the blessed hope—the glorious appearing of our great God and Savior, Jesus Christ,
raw.note: Describes the Christian's hope as the glorious appearing of Jesus.

raw.text: So if you consider me a partner, welcome him as you would welcome me.
raw.note: Paul's appeal to Philemon to receive his runaway slave, Onesimus, as a brother.

raw.text: The Son is the radiance of God’s glory and the exact representation of His being, sustaining all things by His powerful word. After He had provided purification for sins, He sat down at the right hand of the Majesty in heaven.
raw.note: A high Christological statement on the Son's nature and work.

raw.text: but no man can tame the tongue. It is a restless evil, full of deadly poison.
raw.note: A stark warning about the untamable and destructive power of the tongue.

raw.text: Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ! By His great mercy He has given us new birth into a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead,
raw.note: A doxology praising God for the new birth and living hope through the resurrection.

raw.text: The Lord is not slow to fulfill His promise as some understand slowness, but is patient with you, not wanting anyone to perish but everyone to come to repentance.
raw.note: Explains the reason for the delay of the Lord's return as his patience.

raw.text: Behold what manner of love the Father has given to us, that we should be called children of God. And that is what we are! The reason the world does not know us is that it did not know Him.
raw.note: An expression of wonder at the love of God that makes us His children.

raw.text: In a loud voice they were saying: “Worthy is the Lamb, who was slain, to receive power and wealth and wisdom and strength and honor and glory and praise!”
raw.note: The heavenly chorus worshiping the slain Lamb.

raw.text: Let us rejoice and be glad and give Him glory! For the wedding of the Lamb has come, and His bride has made herself ready.
raw.note: The announcement of the marriage supper of the Lamb.

raw.text: And I will put enmity between you and the woman, and between your seed and her seed. He will crush your head, and you will strike his heel.”
raw.note: The Protoevangelium, the first gospel promise after the fall.

raw.text: But He said, “You cannot see My face, for no one can see Me and live.”
raw.note: A statement on the unapproachability of God's full glory for sinful humanity.

raw.text: The LORD your God will raise up for you a prophet like me from among your own brothers. You must listen to him.
raw.note: Moses's prophecy of a future prophet like himself, understood to be the Messiah.

raw.text: I will proclaim the decree of the LORD: He said to Me, “You are My Son; today I have become Your Father.
raw.note: A royal psalm, interpreted messianically, speaking of the Son's divine sonship.

raw.note: A word of comfort and assurance of God's ownership and redemption of His people.

raw.text: The LORD is good to those who wait for Him, to the soul who seeks Him.

raw.text: Rejoice greatly, O Daughter of Zion! Shout, O Daughter of Jerusalem! Behold, your King is coming to you, righteous and having salvation, gentle and riding on a donkey, on a colt, the foal of a donkey.

raw.text: May peoples serve you and nations bow down to you. Be master over your brothers, and may your mother’s sons bow down to you. Cursed be those who curse you, and blessed be those who bless you.”

raw.text: When the dew settled on the camp at night, the manna fell with it.

raw.text: And all these blessings will come upon you and overtake you, if you obey the voice of the LORD your God.

raw.text: And all the people at the gate, along with the elders, said, “We are witnesses. May the LORD make the woman entering your home like Rachel and Leah, who together built up the house of Israel. May you prosper in Ephrathah and be famous in Bethlehem.
raw.note: The blessing of the elders upon Boaz and Ruth at the city gate.

raw.text: And though Judah was the strongest of his brothers and a ruler came from him, the birthright belonged to Joseph.

raw.text: Surely the Lord GOD does nothing without revealing His plan to His servants the prophets.

raw.text: “Behold, I will send you Elijah the prophet before the coming of the great and dreadful day of the LORD.

raw.text: “Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace to men on whom His favor rests.”

raw.text: This is the account of Noah and his family. Noah was a righteous man, blameless among the people of his time, and he walked with God.
raw.note: The introduction to Noah, highlighting his righteousness in a corrupt generation.

raw.text: “And let them make Me a sanctuary, that I may dwell among them.

raw.text: ‘The LORD is slow to anger, abounding in love, and forgiving sin and rebellion. Yet He does not leave the guilty unpunished; He punishes the children for the sin of the fathers to the third and fourth generation.’
raw.note: Moses's intercessory prayer, quoting God's own description of His character, balancing mercy and justice.

raw.text: He is the Rock, His work is perfect; for all His ways are just. A God of faithfulness without injustice, righteous and upright is He.

raw.note: The motivation behind the Tower of Babel: human ambition and fear of being scattered.

raw.text: And he had a dream, and behold, a stairway was set on the earth with its top reaching to heaven; and behold, the angels of God were ascending and descending on it.
raw.note: Jacob's dream at Bethel of a ladder connecting heaven and earth, a symbol of divine connection.

raw.note: The miraculous crossing of the Jordan River, where the waters parted for the Israelites.

raw.text: So give Your servant a discerning heart to govern Your people and to distinguish between right and wrong. For who is able to govern this great people of Yours?”

raw.text: because your heart was tender and you humbled yourself before God when you heard His words against this place and its inhabitants, and because you have humbled yourself before Me and have torn your clothes and wept before Me, I have heard you,’ declares the LORD.
raw.note: God's response to King Josiah's genuine repentance upon hearing the rediscovered Book of the Law.

raw.text: I praise You, for I am fearfully and wonderfully made. Marvelous are Your works, and I know this very well.

raw.text: A wife of noble character, who can find? She is worth far more than rubies.

raw.text: Set me as a seal over your heart, as a seal upon your arm. For love is as strong as death, its jealousy unyielding as the grave. It burns like a blazing fire, like a mighty flame.
raw.note: A powerful poetic description of the strength and permanence of true love.

raw.text: The Spirit of the Lord GOD is on Me, because the LORD has anointed Me to preach good news to the poor. He has sent Me to bind up the brokenhearted, to proclaim liberty to the captives and freedom to the prisoners,
raw.note: The mission statement of the Messiah, which Jesus quoted in the synagogue in Nazareth.

raw.text: My God sent His angel, and He shut the mouths of the lions. They have not hurt me, because I was found innocent in His sight. And also before you, O king, I have done no wrong.”
raw.note: Daniel's testimony from the lions' den, attributing his miraculous preservation to God's intervention.

raw.text: And a voice from heaven said, “This is My beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased!”
raw.note: The Father's affirmation of the Son at Jesus's baptism.

raw.text: “Ask and it will be given to you; seek and you will find; knock and the door will be opened to you.

raw.text: Taking her by the hand, He said to her, “Talitha koum!” (which means, “Little girl, I say to you, get up!”).
raw.note: Jesus raising Jairus's daughter from the dead with a command in Aramaic.

raw.text: He answered, “‘Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your strength and with all your mind’ and ‘Love your neighbor as yourself.’”
raw.note: The lawyer's correct summary of the entire law: the Great Commandment.

raw.text: “Truly, truly, I tell you,” Jesus declared, “before Abraham was born, I am!”

raw.text: “Who are You, Lord?” Saul asked. “I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting,” He replied.
raw.note: The pivotal moment of Saul's (Paul's) conversion on the road to Damascus.

raw.text: They replied, “Believe in the Lord Jesus, and you will be saved—you and your household.”

raw.note: A key verse explaining that God's love was demonstrated through Christ's death for sinners.

raw.text: No temptation has seized you except what is common to man. And God is faithful; He will not let you be tempted beyond what you can bear. But when you are tempted, He will also provide a way out so that you can endure it.
raw.note: A promise of God's faithfulness in providing a way to endure every temptation.

raw.text: God made Him who knew no sin to be sin for us, so that in Him we might become the righteousness of God.
raw.note: A concise explanation of substitutionary atonement, often called 'the great exchange'.

raw.text: For you, brothers, were called to freedom. But do not use your freedom to indulge the flesh; rather, serve one another in love.

raw.text: Put on the full armor of God, so that you can take your stand against the devil’s schemes.
raw.note: The command to believers to equip themselves with spiritual armor for spiritual warfare.

raw.text: that at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, in heaven and on earth and under the earth,
raw.note: A prophecy of the universal submission to the lordship of Jesus Christ.

raw.text: For in Christ all the fullness of the Deity lives in bodily form,
raw.note: A powerful statement on the incarnation, affirming the full divinity of Christ in human form.

raw.text: May God Himself, the God of peace, sanctify you through and through. May your whole spirit, soul, and body be kept blameless at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.
